results.description:
Wanna try us out? Come join us at our water training sessions! No prior experience necessary.


• First two practices are $10 (The $10 can go towards the full membership of $110 for the rest of the season). Pay via Paypal ("Boston 1 - Join us") or venmo (@boston1dboat).

• Also you will not be allowed on the boats if you do not sign the waiver: "Boston 1 e-waiver"


• Make sure to check our Facebook, </a><a href="http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook">http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook for practice announcements and cancellations -- especially in the early and later parts of season with potentially colder night practices. 

Weekly practices are every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday unless a race is scheduled or practice is cancelled.

Mon & Wed: 5:45pm - 8pm, meet 5.45pm on the grassy patch near the Barking Crab.
Sat: 10:45am - 1pm, meet 10.45am on the grassy patch near the Barking Crab.

Optional dinner/lunch or social activity afterwards!

Outdoor paddling means exposure to the weather and water! Be prepared to get wet!

• Clothing: Wear workout clothes, synthetic fibers that dry quickly are highly recommended. Bring dry clothes to change into afterwards.


• Footwear: Sandals or flip flops recommended. Some people go barefoot. Shoes and socks are not recommended.


• Other: Bring plenty of water and sunscreen. Expensive glasses or sunglasses are not recommended. 


All paddling equipment is provided (paddles, pfds). Locked locker provided on-site. Please bring as little as possible to practice as space is limited.

In the event of inclement weather, announcements will be made through the comments area of each meetup event, also in Twitter, Facebook and email alerts.

Sign up for our weekly emails and email alerts

Twitter: @Boston1Dboat

Facebook: http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook

Parking: Channelside Parking at 284 A Street. Enter at 29-41 Necco Street, off Melcher Street. Weekend $6 flat rate.

Restroom: Do not use the restrooms in the Barking Crab, use the public restrooms near the Daily Catch

Public Transport: Closest T stop is South Station on the red line.

Hope to see you there!
results.name: Saturday (4/16) 1st Water training of Season!!!

results.description:
(a set of 6 Saturday classes)


Always wanted to learn how they really fought in the middle ages? Forget any ideas about crude battering on armour; the successful warrior strikes to the gaps and the openings of his or her opponent's attacks, and supplements this with disarms, throws, and other techniques which secure the advantage over larger or stronger attackers.

Around the year 1400, Fiore dei Liberi trained medieval knights and squires, and authored multiple books of medieval combat, some of which have survived to the present day. His method, L'Arte d'Armizare (the Art of Bearing Arms), shows an integrated and cross-referenced system of sword, dagger, grappling, spear & lance, pollaxe and other weapons on foot and on horseback, with and without armour, and easily dispels any illusions that medieval combat was about unskilled strength.

Our beginners' course is six linked classes that give the basic techniques and vocabulary of L'Arte, and enables men and women to begin regular unarmoured training and learning.  No prior training needed; all class equipment is provided.

So, come join the scholars and combatants of our company!

(The price shown is for the set of all six classes (Mar 5, 12, 19, Apr 2, 9 and 16.  There is no class on the weekend of Mar 26) and membership and registration.  Classes are not offered separately.  We'll send an email with some class materials before the first session.)
results.how_to_find_us: Come around to the right side of the school (left side of the church), enter under the green awning then up two flights to the gym!

results.description:
OM (Orgasmic Meditation) is a simple way for people to practice their orgasm. It's like....yoga for your orgasm. And, the more you practice, the more you feel.


The Intro To OM Class is the perfect way to learn OneTaste's signature practice of OM, a simple practice with revolutionary results. Learn how to feel more, connect more deeply to your partner, and enliven your sex in just fifteen minutes a day.

The course will include:
- The philosophy behind OM
- Introduction of a new definition of Orgasm: the difference between Climax and Orgasm
- Exploration of OneTaste principles: Attention, Simplicity & Desire and how they relate to your OM practice
- The benefits of an OM practice
- Live demonstration of OM
- Basic stroking technique
- A chance to have your first OM with the guidance of trained OneTaste coaches (the "OM Lab")


Intro To OM is a great starting point for both men and women, single or coupled, and will give you the right foundation to begin building your OM practice and cultivating your Orgasm.

Open to singles and couples ages 18+ (adults of all genders)
Returning OMers are also welcome - come brush up on your skills!
Pre-requisite: Watch the How to OM Video (available at http://onetaste.us/welcome/)

Intro To OM Course Details:
- Price: $197/person (discounts available is you sign up at a TurnON!)
- 6 hours total includes course, lunch break, and optional OM Lab after the course.


After the class, you can:
- Start your OM practice: we recommend at least three times a week!
- Attend OM Circles (where the community comes together for guided practice) anywhere in the world!
- Join OM Practice Club: a weekly session with local OM coaches to deepen your understanding of OM and increase your facility with the practice. 
- Join the OM Hub: a social network for OMers, where you can interact with OMers in your community and beyond about all things OM!

Registration:
You must register at the eventbrite site - RSVPing on the Meetup page does not hold you a spot, and space is limited.

SO excited to welcome new OMers to the community!

To register for the course, please go to: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/boston-intro-to-om-orgasmic-meditation-april-2016-tickets-21072505431
results.name: Intro To OM Class

Sarah -  Unega Awia (White Deer Song) 

Sarah Surrenders- White Deer Song- Is an Intuitive Healer who uses Sound as her main medium for healing. She is a Shamanic Practicioner, Legally Certified Spiritual Healer, Reiki Certified And Professionally Certified Sound Healer. Sarah leads retreats, workshops, Sound Healing classes, group sessions and offers private healings. Her focus is to help people come into their power, overcome challenges, releasing past emotional traumas, stress and anxiety reduction as well as soothing physical pain. Sarah has had beautiful responses to working on issues surrounding infertility, hormonal imbalance, anxiety, grief, depression and emotional traumas. Sarah travels extensively to pursue her studies, share the magic of sound as a healing tool and to recharge and continue her spiritual nomadic path in service and dedication.

Reviews:


1.Sarah is absolutely amazing, she helped me deal with and move on from issues that had been dormant for many years. The outcome of my sessions was extremely positive and I am forever grateful that Sarah was able to guide me through my healing process with her beautiful sounds! If I could give a 10 star rating, I would. Thank you Sarah!!!! 2. Two years ago I met Sara through a mutual friend at a time I needed healing the most. During her group sessions, she taught us to meditate and calm our thoughts while she played her Himalayan bowls, tuning forks and many other shamanic healing techniques. With her guidance I found an inner calmness and some clarity. After a few sessions I decided I would go deeper into myself and asked for Sara to guide me in private sessions. What happened in these sessions has changed me and given me strength to believe and listen to my inner self all while healing some core issues I haven't dealt with, stemming from as far back as my childhood!  Sara you are an angel among angels. I am grateful. Thank you

3. It's been over a year now and Sarah continues to help me and my family clear our paths and the results have been incredible - and now we are doing this long distance! What a blessing it has been to find this beautiful teacher and guide on our journey. When in the presence of someone whose work is their life's purpose, it can be felt and in Sarah's case, heard! Beautiful sounds creating beautiful results! Feeling lighter and more peaceful. Thank you so much. xo

results.description:
THE DATE: Saturday, April 16, 2016 from 12:00 to 1:30pm

THE RESTAURANT: Himalayan Bistro at 1735 Centre St, West Roxbury, MA 02132

THE BOOK: River of Smoke (The Ibis Trilogy Book 2)

There are 30+ copies in the minuteman Library System.

The Ibis, loaded to its gunwales with a cargo of indentured servants, is in the grip of a cyclone in the Bay of Bengal; among the dozens flailing for survival are Neel, the pampered raja who has been convicted of embezzlement; Paulette, the French orphan masquerading as a deck-hand; and Deeti, the widowed poppy grower fleeing her homeland with her lover, Kalua.
The storm also threatens the clipper ship Anahita, groaning with the largest consignment of opium ever to leave India for Canton. And the Redruth, a nursery ship, carries Frederick "Fitcher" Penrose, a horticulturist determined to track down the priceless treasures of China that are hidden in plain sight: its plants that have the power to heal, or beautify, or intoxicate. All will converge in Canton's Fanqui-town, or Foreign Enclave: a tumultuous world unto itself where civilizations clash and sometimes fuse. It is a powder keg awaiting a spark to ignite the Opium Wars.
Spectacular coincidences, startling reversals of fortune, and tender love stories abound. But this is much more than an irresistible page-turner. The blind quest for money, the primacy of the drug trade, the concealment of base impulses behind the rhetoric of freedom: in River of Smoke the nineteenth and twenty-first centuries converge, and the result is a consuming historical novel with powerful contemporary resonance. Critics praised Sea of Poppies for its vibrant storytelling, antic humor, and rich narrative scope; now Amitav Ghosh continues the epic that has charmed and compelled readers all over the globe.
results.how_to_find_us: Book on the table
results.name: River of Smoke @ Himalayan Bistro, West Roxbury

results.description:
Room to Grow is dedicated to enriching the lives of babies born into poverty throughout their critical first three years of development. Parents are referred to Room to Grow by a network of prenatal programs assisting low-income families. 

Upon their referral, families visit Room to Grow's warm and inviting space once every three months from just before the birth of the baby until their child turns three. During their one-on-one appointments with staff social workers, parents receive developmental information, customized support, and all of the needed baby items to ensure a healthy and secure start for their child.

Volunteers will be sorting, organizing and displaying the thousands of donations of baby items that Room to Grow receives every year.

For more information, please check out the Room to Grow official website: http://www.roomtogrow.org/

results.description:
Join us at this event hosted by Atlas Obscura, my all-time favorite website. They request that you RSVP--the link is on the event's page at http://www.atlasobscura.com/events/obscura-day-2016-the-abandoned-utopia-of-brook-farm . I've pasted the event description below!
-----
Join us on Obscura Day to explore Brook Farm, a Utopian community of the Transcendentalists.

Located alongside an orphan's cemetery, the former site of Brook Farm commemorates the most famous utopian commune to ever have operated in the United States. Established in West Roxbury in April 1841 by the transcendentalists George and Sophia Ripley, Brook Farm (also known as the Brook Farm Institute of Agriculture and Education) sought to equally distribute the tasks of daily life while providing education for all participants; the end goal was a balance of work and leisure that would, above all, benefit the greater good. Unfortunately, turning a profit from the farm's agricultural surplus proved unrealistic and Brook Farm was forced to shutter in 1847.

Nonetheless, the experiment at Brook Farm played a key role in the development of American religious and cultural philosophy. During its heyday, the commune was home to some of America's most renowned thinkers of the period, including Charles Anderson Dana, Greeley, Margaret Fuller, and Nathaniel Hawthorne. Hawthorne would ultimately set his novel The Blithedale Romance in a utopian community modeled after Brook Farm.

This Obscura Day, join three scholars of utopian communities and the literature of New England from the Brandeis University English Department to walk through what is left of the site. This event will give you a chance to explore what remains of the farm, while attempting to convey a sense of its residents' daily life--and their ambitious dreams.
-----
Please remember to register on the Atlas Obscura site as well! http://www.atlasobscura.com/events/obscura-day-2016-the-abandoned-utopia-of-brook-farm

Looking forward to seeing you there!
results.how_to_find_us: I, Louisa, will be wearing a dark-purple coat and dark-blue jeans. My phone number is (857) 544-0492 if you need to text me.
results.name: Obscura Day 2016: The Abandoned Utopia of Brook Farm

results.description:
Part 2!

This is week 1 of our Intermediate track: web development (HTML, CSS, and JavaScript if we have the time/interest)

This course will be progressive, so if you can’t make all 4 weeks, it could be tough to catch up (depending on your kids’ previous experience with these languages). When signing up, please indicate the number of kids you will be bringing. For example, if you are bringing one child, please RSVP "Just Me". If you are bringing two kids, please RSVP "+1". Accurate headcounts are very helpful for planning purposes, and help us deliver the best learning experience possible.

Prerequisites: Kids should have completed a Scratch (or Scratch equivalent) programming course, and be comfortable with basic programming concepts. This course assumes no prior knowledge of HTML or CSS.

What to bring: Laptop (+ charger) with a text editor for coding installed. I recommend Sublime Text 3 (it’s free to try indefinitely). Notepad++ is another good option. Another alternative (though not recommended, because you won’t be able to follow along exactly with the lesson) is to use a browser-based web editor, like codepen.io--this is an option for anyone who only has a Chromebook available.

Location: We’ll be at the LogMeIn office in Seaport. The address is 320 Summer Street, Boston 02210. Map: https://goo.gl/maps/vMvDj. There should be some street parking (bring quarters) as well as a few lots in the area. The nearest T stop is South Station.

Note: We're always looking for mentors, and also non-technical volunteers. If you’re interested in helping out, let us know at [masked], or sign up for the Mentor Mailing List.

Spring session dates (we will open signups for the later dates a week in advance):

• 4/16

• <spring break>

• 4/30

• 5/7

Part 2!


The material covered from last week can be found here: 

http://bit.ly/1S1d00S

, with a little extra code at the end that we didn't get to.


Anyone who would like to join in who was not present for the first session is encouraged to come a little early to the next session so we can make sure everything is running smoothly.


This session is designed for students who have already taken an intro to Python, Java, C/C++, or Javascript course (programming beyond HTML/CSS or Scratch). Exceptions may be granted with instructor permission. Students should be familiar with variables, if statements, and loops. Please arrive prepared with a laptop that already has Python (including scipy, numpy, and matlplotlib packages) installed and running: https://www.python.org/downloads/. If you are new to Python and don't have an environment like Spyder or PyCharm already set up, please use IPython Notebook (http://ipython.org/notebook.html).

The focus of this session will be making music with Python. Depending on student interest and ability, we may cover how computers play music files, how we can create our own digital music, how we can use the computer to distort existing music in cool ways, and ultimately how to make our own music using Python. Under the broader umbrella of digital signal processing, we can also explore topics from speech recognition to medical imaging.

When signing up, please indicate the number of kids you will be bringing. For example, if you are bringing one child, please RSVP "Just Me". If you are bringing two kids, please RSVP "+1". Accurate headcounts are very helpful for planning purposes, and help us deliver the best learning experience possible.

If possible, please email [masked]a brief summary of your student's programming experience and interests. Students are encouraged to explore the online documentation themselves and experiment with running their own code before class.

Spring session dates (we will open signups for the later dates a week in advance):

• 4/16

• <spring break>

• 4/30

• 5/7

results.description:
Are you excited for Summer? Have you been thinking it can’t come soon enough? 

Well, lucky for you, Salsa In the Park is here! 

Join MetaMovements and BU Salsa for a day of pre-summer celebration filled with free music, free dance, free classes and performances! Dance, socialize, join the rhythm in our instrument corner, enjoy the vivid performances we have in store. Engage in the vibrant fun of salsa, celebrate the history, culture and community behind Latin music and dance and feel some of that summer warmth, a few weeks early. 

Have we mentioned it’s free?


WHAT IS SALSA IN THE PARK?


Picture this: It's summer in Boston. At least once a week, under the locust trees of a courtyard patio surrounded by basketball games and children playing, lies 2-3 dance floors that heat up while the cool of the evening and night breezes through. Dance floors are filled with footwork, styling, twists and turns from dance and music lovers from all over Greater Boston! You've entered Salsa In The Park. 

A free and popular outdoor summer series for all ages, backgrounds and abilities, Salsa In The Park is an innovative community engagement project that transforms public space for public benefit through music, dance and education. A public health initiative, featuring movement as a key to wellness, it draws over 500 people from all walks of life every Monday evening from 6pm to 9pm for salsa instruction (dance and percussion), high quality performances showcasing a variety of cultures and genres, social dancing and health and wellness promotion. Our weekly Salsa In The Park is held at South End's Blackstone Community Center courtyard every  summer. 

Many salsa & Latin dancers in Boston claim Salsa In The Park as their favorite event of the city, not only for the appeal of dancing outside "al aire libre," and witnessing engaging performances, but as a way to give back to the community. Dancers, and non dancers, volunteer all summer by donating their time to teach dance lessons to people of all ages and varying abilities; performing at the event; setting up and breaking down the dance floors; assisting with event staffing; maintaining a recycling program; and cleaning up from the festivities late into the night.

results.name: Salsa in the Park- 2016 Kickoff- College Edition!

results.description:
Are you curious about programming or thinking about pursuing a career in software engineering? 

Then RSVP on this meet-up page for this 2-hour Intro to Coding class happening in the Boston area at CIC Boston. Learn the basics of programming, do hands-on exercises, and meet new people. All for free!

The class is being taught by MakerSquare, which runs some of the top coding schools in the country.

Class officially starts at 1:30pm, but please arrive at CIC Boston by 1:15pm to mingle with your fellow classmates and settle in. We will end at 4pm, with the last 30 minutes being an optional Q&A session.

What will I learn during the class?

This beginner ­level class will contain several instructor-guided exercises. The class will cover the following topics:

   1. Overview of programming 

   2. Intro to data & data structures

   3. Basics of functions

We ask that you read the Prerequisites section before the start of class and bring your own laptop (Windows, Mac or Linux) with Google Chrome installed.

What is MakerSquare Boston?

MakerSquare is a three-month full-time school for software engineering. By teaching computer science fundamentals and modern web languages like JavaScript, we prepare students to join top flight engineering teams.

We have campuses all over the country, and are excited to be opening a campus in Boston. The free Intro to Coding class is to introduce more people to the wonderful world of programming and to get the community excited about the launch of our full-time class in Boston in July 2016!

Questions? Email us at [masked].
results.name: Free Intro to Coding Class (Sat April 16, 1:30-4pm)

We'll talk about and practice pacing yourself. If there's a race you're targeting and want to work on that distance or event, let us know and we can help tailor the workouts for you.

We go across the street for pizza (or other food if you don't eat pizza) every week after the swim. Save time to join us! We usually finish up by about 4:30pm.

results.description:
Do you long for greater inner peace?  The live in peace group helps you create more peace, self acceptance, and well being. We can act more confidently with greater clarity.

Our Topic This Afternoon Will ....

... provide you an opportunity to let go of tension, upset, and judgements so that you can experience greater peace.

Many of us have accepted living with tensions in our bodies, with upsets spoiling our mood at unexpected times, with judgments sneaking in. 

Come join us as we practice living our lives more peacefully. 

Peace is not being passive, submissive or indifferent. Peace is an active consciousness that we can learn to enter into, enriching our individual lives, our social situations and the world at large. 

During this evening, we will practice discovering the peace that is always present within us -- no matter what else is going on inside us or outside us in the world.   As we practice recognizing our inner core of peace, we become increasingly able to choose to live in that consciousness of inner peace, even at difficult times of our lives. 

We will look at where we unconsciously practice "against-ness", and learn to let go of that feeling of against-ness, to better work with reality and with the people who surround us. As we let go of "against-ness", we also let go of the upset feelings, prejudices, judgments, tenseness, etc. 

This meeting is sponsored by the Institute of Individual and World Peace (www.iiwp.org)

To Prepare ....

1) When do you feel "against-ness"? 


2) What are the physical signs of your against-ness? (e.g., tightness in throat)  

3) What emotional signs or mental beliefs could be signs of against-ness?

4) How could you be more effective if you were in peace even when bad things happened?

Our Leaders This Afternoon

David Jenkins aspires to live his life more and more in peace. He considers himself a student of living the four principles of peace in his life. This is his highest priority. He is overjoyed to have been involved with the Peacemaker Project for several years. It expands peace in a quiet, loving way, one person at a time.

Emily Page delights in finding joy with others and as an inner process one moment at a time.She's been assisting with Boston Area PeaceMaker Meetings because the simple tools shared go so deep, work so fast and foster such harmony between participants, one session after another. 


Philosophy: The philosophy grounding this work is the realization that peace must start with the individual. One can not fight for peace. If we are going to be a conduit for peace, we must start with ourselves and be in peace. Peace is defined as the absence of againstness. If we can be in peace without being against ourselves or others or situations and encourage others to do the same, then we can be a conduit for peace. 

Facilitators Motivation: We aspire to live our lives more and more in peace. This intention is our highest priority. Participating in these meetings is one way to learn to live our lives more and more in peace. Encouraging others to do the same is strengthening for us all.
results.name: Live In Peace (Peacemakers): let go of tension & upsets allowing more well being

results.description:
I know it is short notice but now the weather looks good for Saturday so lets go! Discover the secret photos opportunities in the South End. I have lived in the South End for nearly 30 years so know all the good photo spots. 

Join me as I lead you on a fascinating walk from the old South End to the new edge. You will see 100 year old brick bow front structures lining small parks, and newly constructed glass and steel building lining the  the expressway. What you capture will be up to you. Helping you take the best pictures possible will be my pleasure.  We will cover quite a bit of ground so wear comfortable shoes and charge up your batteries.

Photo by Boston Guides.

We will meet outside my studio at the Boston Center for the Arts. I will hand out maps and give the first short lesson on how to take great photos of the unique characteristics of this neighborhood. 

Reflections of the old and new along Harrison Ave. South End. Photo by Suzanne

The urban landscape include many fascinating details along with full street scenes. We will work on various assignments designed to build your creative seeing skills. These will include:

• Looking for fresh perspectives and angles

• Seeing the visual elements of color, light, and texture

• Capturing the "grit" (Larry this is for you)

• Experimenting with abstract compositions.

Interior shot of the famous Trolly Barn build in 1891 Photo by Suzanne (we will shoot this)

Photo by Ink Block. Newest condos in the South End. Next to Whole Foods. One block away from the Trolley Barn. 

Remember to apply the Rule of Thirds when shooting abstract subjects to create dynamic tension and visual interest. Photo by Suzanne

I can't wait to show you around my neighborhood. After class we will stop in a local spot for refreshments and view our photos. You are welcome to stay for the social part of the program. Most people love this chance to see the photos of the day. If not you can still post your photos on our site and receive very helpful constructive feedback from the other participants and from me:)

Photo on East Berkley Street South End. By Suzanne

I hope you will join us for this class.  Please RSVP today. Tuition is $45.00

Suzanne

results.name: Fun Photo Walk: Boston South End Urban Landscapes Old and New.

results.description:
We traditionally have a large social meetup twice each month. This gives everyone an opportunity to come and make new friends, practice their Japanese or English, and spend time with a bunch of interesting people from around the Boston area and overseas.  This meetup may be cancelled if there are very few RSVPs.

Close to Boylston on the Green Line, or Chinatown on the Orange Line.
Also a short walk from Park Street or Downtown Crossing. 

• From Boylston Station, go south on Tremont Street (away from Boston Common),  then take a right onto Stuart Street.  The food court will be on your right; you enter the building right by the Dunkin Donuts.

• From Chinatown Station, go west on Boylston Street (toward Boston Common), then take a left onto Tremont Street. Turn right onto Stuart Street. The food court will be on your right; you enter the building right by the Dunkin Donuts.

There is a map of the area below. If you have trouble finding us, please feel free to call or text me at[masked]-2923.  Also you can call or text if you come after we have left for Chinatown, although then there is a greater chance I will miss the call.

Come on by, relax, practice in either language of your choice, and enjoy being part of our growing community!

The Meetup does not end at 6 - instead, some time around there, we usually go out to Chinatown for dinner afterwards to eat family style - anyone who wants to come is welcome. The cost is usually around $12-20/person (not including any drinks for which people pay their own way).  We are open to restaurant suggestions.  However, I am not willing to get into dividing up large numbers of orders on one giant check, which is why we generally go to Chinatown and split everything down the middle.  If you don't want to eat at all, you can come and just enjoy the company for free.  

Please BRING CASH if you can and want to go to dinner - many of the restaurants limit cards to two per table, so if a lot of people have no cash it can be a problem.

Stuart Street view
results.how_to_find_us: We usually have several tables pulled together at the highest point of the food court nearest the elevator.

Hup hup hup! try avoiding ordering drinks just before schedule changes to stay with the group.

SCHEDULE:

5:00-- Foundry on Elm

5:45:  Saloon-- next door. Look for a white globe above the entrance. It's downstairs. There's also (in contrast) a huge music venue just down the hallway frozen in time strait out of the 70's. I think reception will allow you to have a peek.
  6:30 -- Sacco's. Tables are hard to get but the bar area is huge. Have a look at the great wall decor, restored paintings, & the Candlepin Bowling history of Saccos.  Also check out the hand crafted pizza ovens and the human assembly line that creates the pizzas. 

7:15: -- Rosebud (RENOVATED).  If you haven't seen it its completely done over. Also has an indoor terrace. You interested in eating? Get the Asian BBQ Hog Head, or the Smashed potatoes. (Oh but after reading about these you may no longer be hungry). 
  8:00-- Orleans. Has a new cute outdoor patio,

8:45 sharp-- The Burren --BACK ROOM. We'll try and grab CORNER tables there-- all other tables will be removed. Be on time, cover starts at 9:00 Here's the band it's Jimmy's Down. <a>If</a> you want you can leave (get a hand stamp) after 9:00 then get back in free. Also there is free traditional Irish music in the front room starts around 9:30.
   
Zigzag itinerary between pubs ...they're all very near each other so no big deal even if it rains. Don't mean you zigzag... people at my crawls don't get visibly drunk...This is an intentional MIX and MINGLE. M & M's enable you to meet many more people. And get away from people who may pester you.

Davis Square is 2 stops beyond Harvard from Boston on the Red line. Parking lot info:

results.description:
Hi everyone! 

In our April 16th Bible Study we'll study the topic of the "Whole Armor of God". 

The study is based on Ephesians 6:12-18 (text below) where Paul instructs us to put on the whole armor of God including truth, righteousness, the gospel of peace, faith, salvation, and the Spirit.  

Paul's metaphor of "armor" gives us a strong, easy to remember, visual that conveys the importance of each of these elements in giving a Christian a firm relationship with Christ.  Let's discuss together how these elements are needed by a Christian and how we can be sure to put on the whole armor of God!

You're always welcome to come to any Bible Studies that fit your schedule. The studies will be structured as independent sessions, so you won't be lost if you miss one!

I hope you can join us!

Eph 6:12  For we wrestle not against flesh and blood, but against principalities, against powers, against the rulers of the darkness of this world, against spiritual wickedness in high places. Eph 6:13  Wherefore take unto you the whole armour of God, that ye may be able to withstand in the evil day, and having done all, to stand. Eph 6:14  Stand therefore, having your loins girt about with truth, and having on the breastplate of righteousness; Eph 6:15  And your feet shod with the preparation of the gospel of peace; Eph 6:16  Above all, taking the shield of faith, wherewith ye shall be able to quench all the fiery darts of the wicked. Eph 6:17  And take the helmet of salvation, and the sword of the Spirit, which is the word of God: Eph 6:18  Praying always with all prayer and supplication in the Spirit, and watching thereunto with all perseverance and supplication for all saints;
results.name: 1st & 3rd Saturday Bible Study: "The Whole Armor of God?"

Hope to see you Saturday!

Norma

*** Also please bring a lawn/beach chair to sit on ***

results.description:
This is a joint event with Cards & Conversations meetup group so we don't have a waitlist. Tonight is an open game night -- all card, tile, board and party games are welcome. Be sure to bring your favorite one :) If you rsvp "yes" and then have a change of plans please be sure to update your rsvp ahead of time so that you won't be counted as a "no show" and to allow for other members to attend since we have a limit on attendance. Thank you very much.

Live in the Metrowest area and want to come to our events but they're too far away? Want to make some new friends, eat some good food and play some fun games in the process? Make some time on your calendar for Saturday night because we have the event just for you.

While all games are welcome, here are some suggestions for tonight:

American Mah Jongg -- whether you are a beginner or a seasoned pro, we guarantee that there will be a table (or two) for people to play and mingle.

Cribbage -- a lot of people are picking up this game, because it is so awesome. Do you have a cribbage board? If so, be sure to bring it :)

Sequence -- Have you played this game before? The rules are simple but I warn you that it is quite addicting.

We'll be meeting at the Panera in Waltham. Panera offers an inviting setting to meet friends for a light meal and conversation. The bakery-cafe offers innovative salads and sandwiches, delicious baked goods and healthy frozen shakes.

WHAT YOU NEED TO KNOW

This event is free, but please support the group and the event location by purchasing a drink or meal while you are Panera. The food is very good, so it will be hard to resist!

Please do not bring outside food or drinks into Panera.

Note that due to limited space we may place a limit on attendees if too many people sign up (or cancel it if we don't get any at all!)

HOW TO GET THERE

Panera Bread is located at 1100 Lexington Street in Waltham -- in the Shaw's plaza near the corner of Lexington Street and Trapelo Road. Ample parking. Web site: http://www.panera-bos...
Hey Colleen, join the conversation!

results.description:
I loved the animated version of this when I was a kid. I hoping this semi-live action version will be good as well.


Showtime is at 7PM.  We are seeing the IMAX 3D show.  I debated about this, but Rotten Tomatoes said it "sets a new standard in CGI" so it should be worth it to see it in this format.   The movie is showing downstairs.  I will be at the theater around 6.  I will be near the ropes by the concession stand, until they let us into the inner lobby.  We will head in for seats as soon as they let us.    Please note, if you want to sit with the group, please do not be late.

In general, I arrive at the theater an hour before the show to start gathering people, and we head in for seats about 30 minutes before the show, so we can sit together. This also allows us to take turns getting snacks, etc., before the previews start.  It also allows for any unexpected, last minute changes at the theater.  Although fairly infrequent, having wiggle room to exchange tickets, etc. is VERY helpful.

Please note, everyone is responsible for buying their own tickets.  And while it is possible to buy your ticket at the door, shows often sell out. I strongly advise you to buy your tickets in advance.  I will announce when tickets go on sale on Fandango. Please do NOT buy tickets until I have finalized the time.

If you miss the group ahead of time, come find us after. We gather in the hallway outside of the theater we just saw the movie in, to discuss the film a bit, allow for restroom breaks and to get a head count of all those who would like to go out after for drinks and munchies.

$$$$Managing the after event is much easier if everyone brings cash, so please plan ahead if you want to go out with the group after.  We will be splitting one bill for the group. No separate checks.$$$

One more thing, please keep your rsvp's up to date so I can plan the after event and know who to look for.  Thanks!

Movie Details:

Release date: April 15, 2016
(3D/2D theaters and IMAX)

Studio: Walt Disney Pictures

Director: Jon Favreau

MPAA Rating: PG (for some sequences of scary action and peril)

Screenwriter: Justin Marks

Starring: Bill Murray, Ben Kingsley, Idris Elba, Lupita Nyong'o, Scarlett Johansson, Giancarlo Esposito, Neel Sethi, Christopher Walken

Genre: Action, Adventure, Family

Duration: N/A

Copyright Holder: N/A

Copyright: N/A

Official website: Disney.com/TheJungleBook| Facebook| Twitter| Instagram| Pinterest

Plot Summary:

Directed by Jon Favreau (“Iron Man”), based on Rudyard Kipling’s timeless stories and inspired by Disney’s classic animated film, “The Jungle Book” is an all-new live-action epic adventure about Mowgli (newcomer Neel Sethi), a man-cub who’s been raised by a family of wolves. But Mowgli finds he is no longer welcome in the jungle when fearsome tiger Shere Khan (voice of Idris Elba), who bears the scars of Man, promises to eliminate what he sees as a threat. Urged to abandon the only home he’s ever known, Mowgli embarks on a captivating journey of self-discovery, guided by panther-turned-stern mentor Bagheera (voice of Ben Kingsley), and the free-spirited bear Baloo (voice of Bill Murray). Along the way, Mowgli encounters jungle creatures who don’t exactly have his best interests at heart, including Kaa (voice of Scarlett Johansson), a python whose seductive voice and gaze hypnotizes the man-cub, and the smooth-talking King Louie (voice of Christopher Walken), who tries to coerce Mowgli into giving up the secret to the elusive and deadly red flower: fire.

The all-star cast also includes Lupita Nyong'o as the voice of the fiercely protective mother wolf Raksha, and Giancarlo Esposito as the voice of wolf pack’s alpha male Akela. “The Jungle Book” seamlessly blends live-action with photorealistic CGI animals and environments, using up-to-the-minute technology and storytelling techniques to immerse audiences in an enchanting and lush world. The wild adventure swings into theaters in 3D on April 15, 2016
results.name: The Jungle Book (7PM IMAX 3D Show)

results.description:
We will journey inward in a time-honored shamanic method of inner consultation. It is a way of communicating with your inner or spirit self and retrieving information. Your inner self is in constant communication with all aspects of your environment, seen and unseen. You need only journey within to find answers to your questions. Be prepared, however, for whatever insights you may receive, whether you like them or not.
The spirit healing journey is not always what people expect, and sometimes there is uncertainty as to what one should experience in altered states. The ecstatic trance is an individual journey into non-ordinary reality; therefore, experiences vary from person to person and from journey to journey. Once you enter a trance state, the rhythm or sound of the drum tends to change. The drumbeat may appear to speed up or slow down, while the sound may grow louder, softer, or disappear. You may experience a change in body temperature, feel energy flowing through your body, or find yourself twitching, swaying, or rocking. It is not uncommon to hear sounds or voices. You may even smell specific aromas. You may see colorful patterns, symbolic images, or dreamlike visions. Some people may find that they have a highly developed inner vision while others may rely more on instinct, intuition, or intent.
During the spirit healing journey, one's awareness transcends ordinary reality. In journeys to the Lower World, one may experience the sensation of falling, sliding, or spiraling downward into or under the Earth. In Upper World journeys, one may experience the sensation of rising, floating, flying, or spiraling upward through the air or sky. Journeys to the Lower World involve the movement of awareness to a level beneath ordinary reality and Celestial journeys involve movement to a level above ordinary reality. Lower levels are denser, lower in frequency, and more involved with the physical body, the earthly plane, and material reality. Higher levels are higher in frequency, less dense, and subtler.
You will experience at least two spiritual journeys. You do not need prior journeying experiences but an openness of the process and possibilities. Elaine is a training and practicing Shaman and will safely lead you on your journey. Please bring a yoga mat, blanket, something to cover your eyes (scarf), and journal as you may wish to write your experiences immediately following the journey. $10 Any questions or to register please contact Elaine [masked] or[masked]
results.name: An Evening of Shamanic Spiritual Healing This is the last journeying group🌟

results.description:
We will revisit the Boston clock tower, aka Custom House aka Marriott Hotel tower in downtown Boston. The tower top has been remodeled and reopened in February. The location provides a very unique perspective on our city and allows for some spectacular panoramas. 

Main focus of this event: aerial views, cityscapes, city life.

The observation platform on top of the Custom House is publicly available at certain times and has a unique and grand overview of the city. We will arrive before sunset, which is at 7:27 pm, the hotel lets people up 6 and 7 pm, but once up there, we can stay until they close at 11pm. Shooting at night is both challenging (balancing highlights with shadows) and very rewarding for the outcome.

This is an attendance-limited event because the space on the clock tower platform is limited. There is not enough space for more than 12 people and we will need to accommodate hotel guests and other visitors. Please be friendly, considerate and leave a good impression. Even if they bump into your tripod.

Parking garages are nearby, I usually use the 70 State Street garage, which is around $11 after 5 pm and right around the corner. Some street parking may be available, but avoid the Aquarium garage, which is the most expensive in town. Search Google for "parking near..." or download an app named "Best Parking"


We will meet at 6:45 in the lobby of the Marriott hotel. Even though we can stay as long or late as we want, the window to be brought up is 6-7, they may not take you up if you are late. If you don't find us in the lobby, buy your ticket and have the concierge / bell boy take you up. There is a cover charge of $7.50, including a soft drink or $15 including an alcoholic beverage (not worth it), your choice, but you have to pay to be left up.


Challenges:


As you can see from picture #2, the wall is quite high and it has a fence on top of it to prevent you from committing suicide if your photos don't turn out well. In addition, there is an ornate structure build all around the tower, which protrudes out, making it difficult to get a wide angle shot without that showing in the pic. You will need a tall tripod (at least 5+ ft high - native or by extension). If you have a center column that comes out and can be configured as a perpendicular boom (on top of the 6 ft), that absolutely helps to get the lens between the metal bars. I can tell you for sure that small tripods (<5 ft) will not work, especially if they have the legs connected to force it into a triangle. The only way I was able to get shots was by leaning the tripod against the wall with two legs and pushing the third leg close, asymmetrically. Small cameras can even be pushed through the fence to be outside to avoid that ornate structure. Just don't drop it, I will not be responsible for any killed pedestrians. :) Hand-strap highly recommended.

One other thing that works well is a large Joby Gorilla pod, which can be used for smaller DSLR cameras, I used this recently on the Empire State Building. Just hold on tight to make sure it doesn't fall. You can get that with ball head or without ball head (if you have a spare). This is a fairly sturdy little tripod that can be flexed to go around bars. Just make sure to hold on to it.


Dress in layers, count on wind being higher up there than on the ground. Bring gloves head cover, expected temperature is in the mid-40s.


This will be a half-moon night, reducing the contrast between street lights and shadows somewhat. Forecast is for 8 mph winds.


Recommended equipment:

Anything from super-wide / fisheye for sweeping panoramas to super-zoom for close-ups of street life from above, a very unique perspective and lots of opportunities to zoom into. Long zooms only recommended on wind-still days and with a sturdy, tall tripod (I had bad luck zooming in with the gorilla pod on a windy night).


Once you're done up here, you can continue shooting the city around the clock tower, Quincy Market and Copernicus Park are across the street.

This image gives you an idea of the fence that you need to shoot through, and its height:


The next image is at sunset, which gives some nice backlighting:

This image is a typical night photo as you will be taking it:

The last image is a "dynamic zoom", intentional camera motion (ICM) photo, which gives you an idea of how it looks when you zoom in. Lots of interesting activity going on, you will also see the Quincy Market activities.
results.name: Boston from Above: Clock Tower

results.description:
After the movie we'll go out for drinks to discuss the movie and hangout!

“Extraordinary...Thoughtful and fascinating...Godard’s most interesting film since Breathless.”—THE NEW YORK TIMES “An extraordinarily rich and provocative picture...The film heralded a major leap in Godard’s evolution as an artist.”—Calum Marsh, THE VILLAGE VOICE


" Made by legendary French New Wave auteur Jean-Luc Godard at the height of his powers, between CONTEMPT (1963) and ALPHAVILLE (1965), A MARRIED WOMAN is a rarely-seen masterpiece ripe for re-discovery. Godard reverses the standard love triangle and challenges the in uence of consumer culture in the stylish and sensual A MARRIED WOMAN, one of his most playfully provocative dissections of modern life. Shot in striking black-and-white, the lm lingers lovingly on closeups of intertwined nude bodies. During the course of 24 hours Charlotte (Macha Méril), the bourgeois wife of an airline pilot, drifts aimlessly between an affair in the morning with artistic Robert (Bernard Noël), an actor, and spending a mundane evening with her paternalistic husband Pierre (Philippe Leroy). Unsure whether she loves either man, Charlotte discovers she is pregnant and must come to terms with her emotional in delities. From the acclaimed director of GOODBYE TO LANGUAGE, BREATHLESS, VIVRE SA VIE, BAND OF OUTSIDERS, PIERROT LE FOU, HAIL MARY, WEEKEND and MASCULIN FÉMININ. New digital restoration! (France, 1964)"
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at front of lobby near stairs
results.name: A Married Woman

results.description:
MONOLOGUE INTRODUCTION:

My name is Petite Sirah.  I am the love child of Syrah and Peloursin.  I also have an alter ego (Durif).  Under appreciated and unloved in my original homeland in Southern France, I have found new life and purpose in other parts of the world, especially California and Australia.  I even have a fan club these days (http://www.psiloveyou.org). 

Why was I unloved you might ask?  Some think it is the curse all kids have when they have a successful parent.  Syrah was such a star it was impossible to get out of its shadow.  But I think it had more to do with the fact that I just didn’t do well with the environment; my roots kept rotting.  In the new world though, with better sun and climate, I’ve been able to remake myself.  Did you know that skins contribute a lot to wine flavor, color, and tannin?  Given how relatively small a grape I am, with my larger skin to flesh/juice ratio, I make a flavor packed wine, if I say so myself.  Mouth filling, tannic, and meaty, punching above my weight, I am the southpaw of wines. 

If you find me intriguing, come and drink me!

WHAT TO BRING:

·  4 wine glasses

·  1 bottle of petite sirah; durif is okay too

·  1 food item to pair and share
results.name: Petite Sirah

Anderson Comedy is proud to present the hilarious Nick Chambers recording his comedy album!
Born & raised in Worcester MA, Nick Chambers has quickly become a regular at Nick’s Comedy Stop, The Comedy Connection, Comix and other clubs all over the East Coast in addition to being chosen as Comic In Residence at the Comedy Studio in 2014. Nick also made his feature film debut in the comedy “Good Kids” and played the lead role in the drama “It’s Not Funny Anymore”.

results.description: Want to make all your upcoming races seem fun and easy? Join with some other runners on Saturday, April 16th, at the Piety Corner Club in Waltham to drink beer, talk running, and watch an excellent movie on what might be the most difficult running race in the world. I could tell you a story about Lazarus Lake, a weird, quirky character who created this running race. I could tell you how only 10 runners finished the race in its first 25 years. I could even tell you about the race's secret application process, its unknown start time, and how the race is based on James Earl Ray's prison escape gone awry. But that would spoil the fun of watching The Barkley Marathons: The Race That Eats Its Young. Admission is free, but if you are so moved, you may make a small donation to the Waltham YMCA annual fund ( http://support.ymcaboston.org/site/TR/Events/General?px=1020258&pg=personal&fr_id=1130 ). Start time is 7 pm the Piety Corner Club is at 2 Worcester Lane there is parking behind the club. The movie is about 90 minutes long"
results.name: The Barkley Marathon movie

results.description:
It's that time again to play some dodgeball. This is for all levels the rules are explained at the beginning of the game, wear some workout gear and socks to play in, the floor is padded and the balls are soft let's Play!!! .....

$10 cash only paid when you arrive. Then after the game we head over to Orleans (65 Holland street) for cocktails, there is plenty of free parking at both places. This is a multi group event.
results.name: It's Dodgeball Time

results.description:
Let's Play Dodgeball!

Remember when you used to get a lunch break AND recess? Let'slationships were formed while we were playing games-we made friends, scores were settled, and we figured out how to interact with the opposite sex. Well, some of us did :)

https://youtu.be/QPDs4zs3kzw

Remember when you used to get a lunch break AND recess? Let's return to our glory days for some school yard fun! So many relationships were formed while we were playing games-we made friends, scores were settled, and we figured out how to interact with the opposite sex. Well, some of us did :)

Worried about being branded with the logo from the rubber ball? Well, don't...we use soft squishy balls…without a visible logo :) So, if you really hope to get a tattoo, you'll have to find another way.

Dodgeball Details: Teams are chosen round robin style, so it doesn't matter if you ruled the schoolyard at one point. There won't be any awkward "I hope I'm chosen before the kid in the full body cast". The "rules" will be explained by the referee before playing starts. They aren't complex, and there won't be any instant replays for controversial calls.

It's designed to be fun, playful, and casual. The only rule I can remember is not aiming for someone's head. Ladies, I can't guarantee that the guys are going to follow that one : ) Guys, this is still not the best way to get a woman's attention….

All levels are welcome! We will be playing on a padded floor, wearing socks (remember to bring socks!). The arena is air conditioned and is smaller than a typical dodgeball court. There are two individual bathrooms that some people change in. Some people come prepared to play, while others change.

Dodgeball of Boston is located at 1 Broadway in Arlington, MA. There is a small parking lot, emphasis on small, and free street parking available on the side streets. Public transportation is probably the easiest way to get there. It's about one mile from Davis Sq Redline T and Alewife T Stations.

Cost: $10. PLEASE try to pay with a $10 bill, or some combination that adds up to $10 ($5 bills, $1 bills, etc…), as change is hard to make. The cover goes to pay the rent for the space.

After Dodgeball: We will head for drinks/appetizers/Karaoke nearby at:

Orleans Restaurant 
65 Holland Street 
Davis Square, Cambridge

We always have a lot of fun there too, drinking, eating and singing karaoke, and it's a great way to enjoy Friday night!

This will be a joint event with other meet up groups, please only RSVP in one group.

IMPORTANT: Be sure to bring socks with you in order to play and no $20 bills please!

--Carla & Matt 
;-)

https://youtu.be/cXmt_iFLd58
results.name: Dodge The Ball! - Play Dodgeball With Us!

results.description:
So while scrolling on Facebook one early morning in bed I see one of my favorite folk artists is playing locally in Scituate. I immediately bought tickets and discovered a great local find. This venue is amazing for seeing entertainment. 

Steve Sweeney is one of my favorite comedians and is one of the funniest comedians ever to come out of Boston

Buy tickets here $25

https://www.ticketfly.com/purchase/event/1081447?utm_medium=ReceiptOffer&utm_source=tfly

Here's a little sample

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xVhJHz6zIu8

http://www.stevesweeneycomedy.com/biography/

http://static1.squarespace.com/static/538f7623e4b0588b3648728e/t/53a20bf9e4b01756877cb291/1403128826139/?format=300w

Born in Charlestown, Steve Sweeney is a legendary Boston comedian known as a master of dialects and character voices. With his famous Boston accent and great insight into human nature, Steve is so thoroughly Bostonian that he merits his own stop on the MBTA Green Line.

Steve learned his craft at the world famous Ding Ho Comedy Club, where he performed with Lenny Clarke, Denis Leary, Jay Leno, and more. Well-rounded and seasoned, Steve has kept audiences laughing for years. He won his status, the old-fashioned way – he earned it!

He has been a featured on major television shows including David Letterman, Evening at the Improv, Comics Come Home, and Comedy Central, and starred in his own Boston-based sitcom, Park Street Under.

Steve’s trademark political satire has earned him top host spots on Boston radio stations 100.7FM WZLX (Sweeney’s Neighborhood) and 95.9FM WATD (Jay Mohr and Opie & Anthony.) In addition, Steve is an elite Master of Ceremonies selected by many charitable and political organizations (of both parties, but separately, of course!)

 Steve is a successful actor and has appeared in many Hollywood films, which include:

The Forger [2014]

The Equalizer [2014]

Me, Myself & Irene [2000]

There’s Something About Mary [1998]

Next Stop Wonderland [1998]

Southie [1998]

Celtic Pride [1996]

Back to School [1986]

Steve lives just outside his hometown of Boston and when not working loves to spend quiet time with his dog and friends.

The Venue.... http://www.theriverclubmusichall.com/

I'll be posting more here. It was a great place for an event.

I saw David Wilcox there recently -  a great show and a wonderful venue
results.how_to_find_us: Let's meet at the bar - my cell is - 508-479-7690
results.name: Comedian Steve Sweeney - Scituate

results.description:
Event Organizer: Michael Blair @ (978)[masked]


=====

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

Answers DO NOT carry over from one event to another so you must answer them for EACH EVENT. Also, questions might not show up if you RSVP from a phone or tablet so if you don't see them you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you RSVP.

=== What We're Doing ===

The plan is to hike to three of the 4,000 footers in New Hampshire - Madison, Adams, and Jefferson. We will use Lowe's Path and Randolph Path to get to Jefferson and then head over to Adams and Madison before coming down on Valley Way. The AMC's Madison Spring Hut is closed for the season.

If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months.

RSVPs close 24 hours before the event.

The maximum group size for this trip will be 12 people. 

Guests aren't permitted.

Dogs are only permitted with prior approval of the event organizer.

=== Trip Summary ===

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

On this moderate pace (~2.0 MPH) trip we will hike about 13.3 miles and climb about 6,100 feet. It should take an average hiker about 10 hours to complete (this doesn't include time taking breaks). This event is considered ADVANCED because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.

Use this link for more information about where we are going and how we will get there:

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/3-Mt-Jefferson-5712

• http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/2-Mt-Adams-5774--5-Mt-Madison-5367

Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants.


Use this link for the current weather forecast:

• http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=44.320339409000496&lon=-71.29090635799963#.Voh8wDblw3I


=== What to Bring ===


While I don't think that we will need snow shoes we might still need traction - either Kahtoola Microspikes or Hillsound Trail Crampons.

Use this link for a list of items needed for a three season day hike: 

• http://files.meetup.com/492954/Three_Season_Dayhike_gear_list.pdf

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

=== Directions ===

We will meet at the Appalachia Trailhead which is located on the north side of Route 2 south of Gorham, NH. According to Google Maps this spot is about 170 miles from Boston and it will take about 2 hours 47 minutes to drive there. Since this is where we will end the day we will leave a few cars there and drive a short distance to the starting spot.

Use this link to customize the driving directions:

• https://goo.gl/maps/D2Qf9kmqmg72

While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride.

=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.

It takes approx 2 hours.   It is a nice hike mostly on Cart paths with rolling hills mixed in.. We will meet at 156 S. Row Road, in Lunenburg. We will not leave anyone behind.  Socially behaved dogs are welcome, please bring your own doggie bags. 

NEW !!!!!! PLEASE TAKE NOTE: The time has changed and sneakers are not recommended.
Directions.
From the center of Lunenburg
Rte 2A East Approx 3/4 mile turn left onto Townsend Harbor Road.
Travel approx 1/2 mile on Townsend Harbor Road to the stop sign. Turn left at the stop sign to continue on Townsend Harbor Road.
Travel approx another 1/2 mile at the fork stay left onto South Row Road. Follow South Row Road for approx 1/2 mile.
My house is on the right.
Uturn Driveway, Brown house. Pull right into the driveway.

We meet for 9:00 and try to take off promptly.  

IF YOUR PLANS CHANGE, PLEASE CHANGE YOUR RSVP!

Thank you, I look forward to another successful hike.

Cannabis Society has been invited to participate in the Babson Cannabis Symposium!  Returning for the second year, the Babson Cannabis Symposium is bringing together “budding” entrepreneurs and industry experts from the Massachusetts area to discuss the evolving landscape surrounding Marijuana. Focusing on the fastest growing industry in the nation, this event provides an opportunity to educate the Babson community on the potential opportunities in the booming market. 

We believe that there is no better place for this event due to Babson’s established prestige in the realm of entrepreneurship. The purpose of this forum is not to promote marijuana use on campus, rather to provide a holistic approach in educating Babson professionals on the industry from experienced leaders in the field. Not only is the event a unique learning experience, it will serve as a tremendous networking for anyone looking to pursue further opportunities. We want this event to be fun and relaxing for both the speakers and the attendees.

Dress: Business Casual

FREE FOR EVERYONE BUT DONATIONS ARE ACCEPTED!

RSVP here:  https://babsoncannabis.splashthat.com/

The Cannabis Society is Growing  

Our group has grown by leaps and bounds these past few years and we are proud to announce that the Cannabis Society is going to continue to grow and develop our ecosystem with groundbreaking events centering around medical cannabis, technology, art, and science. We couldn’t do it without our members and we want to thank you for being apart of this growing organization.

This workshop is for anyone who has never played around with Arduino before and those who have played around a little bit but aren’t entirely sure about how the basics work. It’s easier than you think!

We will put together basic single component electrical circuits, learn about analog and digital, input and output, basic programming concepts, practice very basic Serial communication, and briefly cover basic virtual prototyping.

In case you haven’t noticed the key word here is "basic."

Students will create three simple circuits highlighting analog and digital forms of input and output. Get started with the Arduino programming environment; briefly discuss programming and virtual prototyping.

Concepts that will be covered include:

Using a breadboard
Ohm’s Law
Digital and Analog
Input and Output
Arduino programming environment basics
Serial Monitor usage with text, variables and pin states

Instructor: Sajin George

results.description:
The sudden snow on top of the rain made the original date for this hike potentially too hazardous so we rescheduled it for the same time two weeks later.  The following is as it was:  This hike will take us an estimated two hours and is approximately 3.5 - 4 miles long.  For the first 1.5 miles we will be walking part of the paved loop that encircles the park before reaching the trail head, and then we will shift into "four wheel drive" for the elevating and panoramic Ridge Trail.  

This hike is a bit more challenging than the previous "ponds hike", involving a lot of "ups" and "downs" as we will be reaching some of the highest points in the park (If we were to rate this hike on a scale of 1 - 5, 1 being flat paved road, the ponds hike being a 3, this is a 4 - 4.5).  On a clear day you can easily spot the Boston skyline and ocean points like Revere Beach, as well as local landmarks and overviews of the park. You can add some rocks to the cairns that mark some of the peaks and plateaus, see beautiful vernal pools, and hike to Castle Rock, the highest point in the park, which will be our final rest stop before descending to the end of the trail. 

Outside of the paved road, the terrain is quite varied with raised roots and muddy areas, and plenty of rocks.  Some segments of the hike, particularly the peaks and plateaus are all rock and often uneven.   Hiking boots with good traction and support are an absolute must.  If you have any ankle or knee issues this may not be the hike for you.  As always, there are a number of points where our hike intersects or parallels the main road should you need or want to leave the trail for any reason.

If there is interest, participants can enjoy lunch together afterward at a restaurant on nearby Route 1.  There is plenty of parking by the Vo Tech School on the wooded side of the lot.  We will meet by the large metal gate at the entrance of the park.  If it rains, the event is cancelled.  If conditions are very wet, we will choose an alternate, safer course for the hike.
results.name: Hiking the trails of the Breakheart Reservation - RESCHEDULED Ridge Trail Hike

results.description:
When you Lead, do you want to be…Genuine? Compelling? Powerful?


Successful leadership communication relies on the power of your presence. It is your ability to be fully and genuinely present and connected with others whenever you deliver a talk, lead a meeting, or speak to just one individual that matters.

The mistake leaders make is to put a priority on their content rather than on the human connection.

By learning the Leadership Presence skill in a Speaking Circle you will be able to compel rapt attention naturally.

You will learn how to…

Be present and engage your listeners

Express your ideas and vision clearly

Speak naturally and with authority

Speaking Circles help:
* Business professionals who want to become more effective, authentic and powerful.
* People who want to be more fully present, confident and authentic.
* People who suffer from stage fright or "being shy".

I hope you'll join us,

Dexter Nardella

To see my personal meetup site and a listing of Speaking Circles on other dates go to: http://www.meetup.com/Newton-MA-Public-Speaking-Meetup/

Our Speaking Circle supports you to learn how to express yourself -- in your own time and in your own unique way -- without fear and without discomfort. 

Some call this authentic expression, “speaking from the heart,” “the authentic self” or “your real voice.”   Whatever you call it, you will know when you are there and you will be able to tell when someone else is there. 

Click to read FAQs about a Speaking Circle. http://www.speakingcirclesinternational.com/Articles/Principles/FAQ.html#.VKx9y0c76rU

See and hear participants talk about their experience in SPEAKING CIRCLES:


http://youtu.be/Wi82ZIgioh0

Leader:

Dexter Nardella is a certified Speaking Circle® facilitator trained by Lee Glickstein, the originator of Speaking Circles. <a></a>He first experienced Speaking Circles in 2004 when he was looking for a way to feel at ease speaking to the audiences he addressed as a chiropractor. 

During my many years as a chiropractor, I often explained to patients that within each one of us there lies a wise 'healing system' capable of fighting off disease, combating infection and bringing us greater energy, vitality and well-being.  Now, the simple guidelines of a Speaking Circle invite participants to discover a direct extension of that wisdom. The experience of witnessing participants speaking from that quality of presence is nothing short of amazing.

My calling is to help people be present to who they really are and to speak from that presence.  It would be my privilege to support you on your journey. Join us in speaking from the heart and relax into the wonder of being yourself.
results.name: Speaking Circles: Leadership Presence -- How to Connect and Inspire

results.description:
What to expect: This monthly meeting typically begins with an introduction all around for the benefit of any first-time attendees, and discussion of any announcements, upcoming events, etc. We then move on to a topic of interest to atheists (usually) chosen beforehand. Sometimes participants bring print-outs of articles, research, or books to share on the topic, and sometimes people just come with a story or opinion to share.

We loosely moderate the topical discussion to give everyone a chance to participate. Then the conversation often flows onto other related subjects, sometimes in smaller conversation groups around the table.

If you have any ideas for meeting topics, please let any of the co-organizers know. We can also add announcements or "mini-topics" on the agenda if there's anything you'd like to share with the group.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the large group at a back table; some might be wearing atheistic shirts.
results.name: Sunday Morning Topical Meeting

results.description:
Vaccines are a volatile subject these days. Some folks believe more is better while others refuse even a single jab. In either case, these parents believe they are doing the best they can for their children.

Let's get together to uncover the truth about vaccines in a non-dogmatic space and give you the tools you need to think and choose for yourself.


We'll talk about

• The effectiveness of vaccines

• The risks vs the benefits

• What the vaccines are actually preventing

• The potential side effects

• How to choose vaccinations for your kids (and yourself)

• How to manage the mercury exposure in vaccinations

• How to minimize the risk of severe adverse reactions

This is a serious topic that should be considered by every single parent. I hope you'll make time to educate yourself for the health and safety of your children.


See you there!

Big Love,
Bee
results.name: Vaccines: Everything you need to know to make informed decisions

results.description:
Come join us at our regular Scrabble Meetup, and play over lunch or a pastry and some coffee!

We meet twice a month, every month, on the first and third Sunday. Please bring a board if you have one. We have a few spares, so you are welcome to come even if you forget your board.

Newcomers are always welcome. We keep 2 and 3 letter "cheat sheets" for new folks to keep the playing field more even.

We mostly play Scrabble one-on-one, and pairing is random. If you would like to be matched up to someone of a similar skill, just let the organizer know.

Au Bon Pain is right next to the Davis Square T stop, and there is typically ample free street parking on Sundays.  A few times a year, there is a race in Davis Square that shuts down some streets, so keep an eye out for that. If possible I will send out a message to the group the day before.

$2/Meetup goes to help pay for the annual Meetup.com dues and miscellaneous photocopying, but if you are a regular $15/year will be easier for you and me to keep track of!
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the people with Scrabble boards out--the cafe is usually empty on Sundays.

results.description:
Astrology Series: Moon Exploration

Sunday, April 17, 2016             12:30 pm

Everyone knows that the sun is a very important placement in the horoscope, but did you know that the other luminary, the moon, is, too?

Using your personal natal chart, you will explore the moon and its meaning in your chart and in your life. The moon represents a number of aspects in your life, including your emotions and emotional nature/patterns. Come to a better understanding of why you feel the way you do and how you respond emotionally to various relationships and circumstances.

Patricia Mellman is a professional astrologer and is conducting this workshop.

Workshop: $25, payable at the door or, if you are taking Introduction to Astrology on Saturday, April 16, this workshop fee is due at that time.

Note: this workshop series is for entertainment purposes only

results.description:
Small Doggy Playdates is conveniently held at The Meadows Pet Resort and Spa in Holliston, 140 Summer Street. We meet mostly every 3rd Sunday of the month, 1:00 pm - 2:30 pm.


The Meadows is a multi-million dollar pet resort. The resort provides us with a large, clean indoor room with windows, chairs, water bowls, and plenty of room for our small dogs to play and socialize. Your dog can run around and play with others, off leash, in a safe environment.  

• All small and toy breeds are welcome. We look forward to having owners of FRIENDLY, EASY-GOING small dogs (under 20 lbs), with GOOD DOGGY MANNERS come play and make new friends. Please be sure your small dog(s) is healthy, clean, spayed or neutered, flea-free, and up-to-date with shots. If your pup(s) shows aggression or excessively barks towards others, you may be asked to leave.

• Due to the increase in participation at our PlayDates in Holliston, parking has become limited. The Holliston Meadows staff has asked us to please park directly across the street at Fatima Shrine where there is ample FREE parking for all. 

• Due to some food allergy-prone dogs, please refrain from feeding your dog treats or snacks during the PlayDate. Their Moms and Dads will greatly appreciate this.

results.description:
Yes, I'm doing a *Bonus* feast in April. No, I'm not crazy (that's up for debate). I am, however, crazy about YOU and this GROUP! (Over 300 members in 6 months, yikes! You guys amaze me.)


Here's how this *Bonus* feast event idea came about . . .


One of our original members, Karen, reached out and inspired me to come up with a "healthier" focused feast. Not a bad idea, right? (Especially after our indulgent, decadent, buttery, yet heavenly Julia Child feast—it was glorious and unforgettable).


I didn't have any immediate ideas on what would be fun, healthful, educational and, most importantly, delicious. Plus I had our entire year of events fully mapped out, and was hesitant to make any changes.


Then it hit me . . . For the last few weeks, I have been obsessing over a new book, Simple Green Smoothies. I make them for myself and for my 2 year old son. We both LOVE them! The book—and blog—has truly inspired and challenged me while nourishing my family. So the thought occurred, "Why not create a *Bonus* feast and share in this experience with each of you?!" (Thank you, Karen!)


This event is going to be similar to our traditional feasts, but with a twist. Instead of a buffet of food to partake in, this feast will be a showcase of green smoothies to sip and sample.


Yep! We're each going to pick a smoothie recipe to prepare (ahead of time), bring it in to share, and drink "shot glass" sized samples of all the smoothies. It's the perfect way to try a variety of smoothies in one sitting without have to buy all the ingredients! Pretty sweet, right? NOTE :: I don't think you have to double the recipe. Each recipe serves 2-3 adults.


I'm definitely going to bring my copy of the book with me so I can tab recipes I like best. Put my custom post-it notes to good use! ;-)

If you don't have a copy of the book, feel free to use a recipe from the blog. Please be sure post the link in the comments section and bring a printed copy with you, too. Otherwise, we'll focus on the array of green smoothie recipes from their book. See links below. I'm always happy to snap some pics and email them to you.


BLOG LINK :: SimpleGreenSmoothies.com

BOOK LINK :: Amazon.com (or you can get it at Barnes & Noble)
results.name: *Bonus* feast — Simple Green Smoothies

results.description:
This will be our first beginners hike of the season!  Let's try to get some of our new members out there.  Come join us for an enjoyable, easy barefoot hike at the Mass Audubon Broadmoor sanctuary.  Broadmoor has a number of very easy, clean trails which are ideal for new barefoot hikers.  We will cover between one and three miles depending on how those in the group feel.  These trails are leaf and pine needle covered woodland trails running through a beautiful wildlife sanctuary.  This time of year there could be some mud and water on the trails, not a problem for bare feet!!

Each hiker should bring water and tick repellant.  Ticks are a serious problem in Mass.  Those new to going barefoot should bring backup shoes to get over the gravel lead in.  Instruction will be provided before and during the hike.

Meet at the end of the parking lot nearest the nature center.  Look for barefoot people.  There is a five dollar charge to enter the preserve unless you are a Mass Audubon member.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for barefoot people in the parking lot
results.name: Beginners barefoot hike at Broadmoor

results.description:
Hi  All,

Spring is finally getting closer and Sunday is supposed to be a beautiful day! So let's sketch outside at the Boston Harbor Walk and Institute of Contemporary Art. The harbor walk has been a revitalization project many years in the making and contains 38 miles of the trail. 

The walk's Fan Pier Park sits next to the Boston Institute of Contemporary Art which was built in 2006. The structure echos the nearby waterfront gantry cranes and was the recipient of the Harleston Parker Medal in 2007 for most beautiful piece of architecture in Boston. 

Bundle up some still, because it gets a little cooler by the ocean. So let's enjoy this beautiful weather and sketch outside! Hope to see you there!

- Miriam
results.how_to_find_us: I will be in the park with a dark blue messenger bag with green and white flower shapes.
results.name: Let's Sketch! Boston Harbor Walk
