results.description:
If you're struggling in any area of your life as a man, particularly in the area of relationships with women, then you need to check this out.

Here's what this is all about:  My friend Milt Evans has agreed to do a special "group coaching" event just for the men in this group.  This is an awesome opportunity to get personal feedback and help from someone who has decades of wisdom and a wealth of precise knowledge that he can apply to your specific challenges.

Milt has counseled and mentored hundreds of men in his life in all the areas that are important to us.  Things like:

How to be the kind of man that women find attractive and want to stay with.

What to do when women start freaking out and becoming difficult.

How to handle specific relationship challenges (bring your worst problem, and Milt will help you).

What to do if you're feeling "lost" as a man, and how to get back to discovering and living your life's purpose.

And so much more.

Milt is the one man whose advice I rely on whenever I'm faced with difficulties in life.  There's no point in relying on trial and error when you've got a friend who has seen your situation over and over again and knows how to steer you through it effortlessly.  He's helped me personally with things like:

How to handle and stand up to bullies without being violent.

How to be the man in my relationships with women so that they gladly follow my leadership.

He's pointed out specific errors in my thinking that were causing distance between me and others.  Once I made the corrections, those problems dissolved as if by magic.

And plenty of other things.

Milt does not get up on stage and lecture like I do.  He works in small groups by talking to one man at a time about his issues.  And even though I've learned tons by talking with him directly in these groups, I've actually learned MORE from listening to him coach other men, and you will too.

Now listen, I realize you don't know this man, and so you're going to have to make your decision based on your relationship with me... Jason.  If you trust me, and if I've helped you in the past, then you already know that if I am endorsing this man, you can trust him as well.

So if you want to become the kind of many who is living each day powerfully and is magnetically attractive to the kind of women YOU want, then I urge you to attend this one-of-a-kind coaching event being held at my place.

************************************************* 
HOW TO GET INVOLVED 
*************************************************

Where is it? This event is going to be at a private home in Arlington, MA. It's very easy to get to both by car and public transportation, and there's plenty of on-street parking. Directions will be emailed to you. We will start the event promptly at 7:00pm and run until 9:00pm. Please plan on arriving by 6:45 so you have time to settle in and meet the other guests. You never know who you'll meet that can become a new friend and add a lot of value to your life.

How much? Cheap.  Milt's accumulated wisdom spans many decades.  For you to be able to get help with your personal challenges by a man as wise and experienced as Milt, you'd have to pay at least $100 for a private counseling session.  But because this is in a group format, you're getting in for much cheaper.

So how much? Because I want to help as many people as I can, I've decided to keep the price very affordable so that anyone who wants to come will be able to.  The cost for this event is only $20, which is very low considering the quality of training that you'll be getting.

Think about it... that's 67 cents a day for a month.  What else do you spend 67 cents on every day that makes no difference in your life whatsoever? I promise that this will be well worth your time, and like I said... you'll learn just as much (if not more) from listening to him coach other man as you will from him coaching you.

How big is the class? Because this is class is being held at a private house and not a large seminar room, I have to limit the size to only 10 men.  I'm listing this in a few groups, so there will be at least 1,000 other men seeing this message, so be sure to put in your RSVP right now in order to lock in your spot.

Go ahead and put in your RSVP right now in order to secure your spot.  I'm looking forward to seeing you there.

Warmly,
Jason

P.S. - Take down my cell number in case you have any questions about the event or if you get lost. The house is extremely easy to find, so you should have no problems, but just in case, my cell is:[masked]-8871.
results.name: Attention Men - A Rare Opportunity To Get Coached By Milt Evans

About March 1 our 500th member joined this Meetup group so let's play for $500!  See a video of our 500th member below ;-)


We will be playing Pop Quiz at Orleans in Davis Square. This is one of the nicer venues offering trivia.  The format is similar to Stump!  We'll want to be as on our game as possible since the prize potential is high but we have to get at least 14 of the regular 16 questions correct and all the between quarter questions correct to win the $500 prize.  With less correct we can still get a $50 gift card for 1st place. The between quarters questions are tough as we need to name 4 football teams, or 4 states, or 4 movies etc.  For less than all 4 we still get the points but miss the $500.

We tried this before, with a group of 7 or 8 good players and took first place but were one answer shy of the $500 prize.  We did win the first place $50 gift card.


We can have up to 8 on our team and we need a diverse knowledge base so please be sure to answer the RSVP question.


• This meetup is especially for those who have played with the group at least twice previously.  Newer members are welcome to sign up.  However, attendance is limited to 8 and if there is the wait list I may move older members from the wait list to the Yes list and vice versa until about 48 hours before the event.


Trivia starts at 8:00 & ends at about 10.00. Please arrive at 7:30 to eat, drink, and socialize.

UPDATE: Monday Morning April 18.  I just called Orleans and made a reservation.  I also inquired and learned they no longer offer the $500 prize.  We still can win a 'normal' prize and we will have a good time.

results.description:
The Public Open Night at the Observatory is a chance for people to come observe the night sky through telescopes and binoculars and see things they otherwise might not get to see, and learn some astronomy as well. The Open Nights are held most Wednesday evenings throughout the year, weather permitting.

The program starts promptly at 7:30pm during the fall and winter months,and 8:30pm during the spring and summer months.

Please arrive early as there is no admittance once the program begins.

We start admitting ticketed guests 10 minutes before the program begins.

Right before the program starts and after all the ticketed guests that are present are admitted, we will admit any non-ticketed guests until we reach capacity.

Weather
The weather is always a factor when observing. Unfortunately we can’t control the weather and we can’t observe when there are clouds, haze, or rain; so when the weather is bad, the Open Night will be canceled. Predicting the weather in New England isn’t easy, so we won’t know if the Open Night will be held or not until the day of the program. This lets us make the decision as late as possible while still giving those who live farther away time to get here. Remember, it gets very cold in Boston in the winter and the telescopes are outside, so dress warmly.

To find out if the Open Night will be held, call our information number at[masked], or check our Twitter feed (twitter.com/buobservatory): no earlier than two hours before the scheduled starting time.

Location
The Public Open Night is held at the Coit Observatory at Boston University. We are located at 725 Commonwealth Avenue in Boston, MA, above the Astronomy Department. The stairwell up to the Observatory is on the fifth floor just to the left of room 520.

Unfortunately, there is no disabled access to the Observatory.

Information
For information about Open Night, please call[masked], or check our Twitter feed (twitter.com/buobservatory):

Source(s):
New member, Manny reminded me about...
http://www.bostonastronomy.net/Public%20Viewing.html
http://www.bu.edu/astronomy/events/public-open-night-at-the-observatory/

Watch for tickets here:
http://www.eventbrite.com/e/boston-university-open-night-tickets-20559405736
results.name: Boston University - Public Open Night at the Coit Observatory

results.description:
This is the regularly scheduled Wednesday Night MeetUp for the Martial Arts


Together In Motion has opened their gym for our group for Tuesday Nights typically to 9:30 PM


7:30 to 8:00 is centered around those with limited background and the focus is on a basic physical Self Defense system incorporated with progressive boundary setting.

8:00 on the pace picks up with a very open format gathering of Martial Artists of diverse backgrounds who work until everyone gives in to the night.

Donations are always welcome and go towards Not Me! a non profit organization dedicated to providing instruction, conditioning and training to at risk populations

Visit Not-Me.Org if you would like information on the group the donations benefit.

This open mat time is open to all levels and backgrounds of martial arts, typically this is a self directed group which allows everyone to work on practice of their choosing.

Past meetups have had flow drills, throwing practice, locking practice, punching mitt and kicking targets. This really is an open format which allows members to question what they have been taught, share with others and just practice with no pressure of joining a school or formal system.

If you've been out of practice for years or months but want to start doing something again this is the place!

Please join us with a friendly spirit, bring whatever equipment you have or just yourself, uniform or running shorts makes no difference to us. The Together in Motion facility has a large open area with raised spring hard wood floor with dense mats covering, so it is adaptable for just about any type of practice.

Mat shoes or Socks are preferred on the practice surface

results.description:
Following the recent theme of making predictions, for this week's game night we'll play Wits and Wagers. This is a trivia game for people who don't know trivia. Everyone guesses at the answer to an obscure numerical question like "In feet, how tall was the tallest giraffe ever recorded?" or "What percent of U.S. households own at least one pet?" Then we make wagers on which one we think is the closest to the truth.

It's the best training I've found for reasoning about uncertainty, and at the same time somehow manages to be a hugely entertaining game.


Our schedule is as follows:

• 7:30 Arrival and introductions

• 8pm Game begins

• 11pm End

Attendees are welcome to bring snacks, drinks, or game recommendations.
results.name: Wednesday Game Night: Wits and Wagers

results.description:
Join 50 to 80 or 100 dancers any Wednesday at Dance Freedom!!

We are the original barefoot weekly dance, continuously running for 44 years, that has spawned hundreds if not thousands of other dances around the world.

In a drug, alcohol, and shoe-free environment, we've been making friends and sharing safe and juicy dances for decades. Come join the fun!! Discover the joy of dancing in a totally non-judgmental atmosphere, where anything safe and respectful goes... dance by yourself, in a group, with a same or opposite sex partner, or even just chat and enjoy watching.

First time visitors are welcomed heartily, and get in for half price! Otherwise, you decide what to pay in a range from $10 to $20, or less later in the evening as the event nears its end (information on late admission discounts is at the door). Our friendly dancers range from utterly new at it to very skilled dancers in funk, rock, salsa, modern, jazz, hip-hop, African & Latin and swing, tango, contact improvisation, and our own unique spontaneous creations! Dance with or alongside amazing dancers from local dance troupes as well as with ordinary good-hearted rug cutters. At work they may be doctors, lawyers, programmers, massage therapists, expressive therapists, artists, students, dog walkers, scientists, or anything else, but at heart they all love to dance.

The music runs the gamut: funk, world music, soul & r&b, house, trance, hip-hop, salsa, yoga music, jazz or swing, reggae, disco, you name it! Each DJ from our rotating list has a unique style, but we try to include something for everyone in every set. We keep a good balance in the music: familiar with unusual, timeless with current, melodic with drum-based, and positive lyrics with instrumentals--in all kinds of rhythms & styles! In any given evening, the world music parts of our dance are likely to include at least 3 or so of the following... African, Latin, Indian, Middle Eastern, Caribbean, zydeco, gypsy and much more. You'll hear everything from basic party music to very danceable songs with socially conscious lyrics, but you won't be hearing anything sexist, racist, violent, hating or otherwise divisive.

Start with a soothing stretch and warm up at 7:30, connect with the group and start to boogie at 7:50 with our first DJ of the evening, take a brief break at 8:50 for community announcements and a short unique performance or workshop (or chatting & stretching in a way that doesn't interfere), then cut the rug again by 9:15 at the latest with the evening's second DJ, till 10:30--plenty of time for a great workout and some feel-good inspiration and respiration and perspiration!

At the beginning of each half of the evening's music, everyone who wants to gathers around a centerpiece to hold hands, and dance in a winding chain together to a song with uplifting, connective (or at least beautiful and hypnotic) slow to medium tempo rhythms. (This dance was created from out of a drumming circle on the Cambridge Common in the sixties, after all, and some of that great political and community spirit still lives on here.) Then, it's all dance music, generally building in tempo to a crescendo, slowing down again for some more melodic and slow dance songs for a few minutes, then gradually building to a second crescendo. The second half of the evening's dance follows roughly the same pattern with a different DJ and style, and ends with another circle dance for those who enjoy it.

Dancers are always welcome to help with set-up or take-down, and get in free for doing so! It's a great chance to get to know the community better and be serviceful, as well as to save money and help us to be around for another 42 years... Welcome! For more information, E-mail: [masked]

results.description:
Kangoo Jumps is one of the latest fitness crazes catching on across the country.  It's an amazing workout for people who are interested in losing weight and building strength. Great for those who want a high intensity cardio workout with far less impact to their joints. Kangoo jumps can burn up to 50% more calories than traditional workouts.

                                                    Meetup Details:

Organizer/Event Host: 
Jenna (*SHC)

Kangoo Jumps Instructor: 
Wendel C.

Sponsored by: 
Kangoo Jumps Club - MA.


Choreography Level:
Easy, basic steps, entry level

Cardio Level:
High Intensity Workout

Location: 
Abington

Cost: 
$15.00 with Kangoo Jumps rental - $10.00 without rental, * Special rate pricing avail to SSH&B/SHC members only.

Attendance Limit:
10 members, limit may increase as needed later.

Gear/Clothing:
Bring 2 pairs of thick socks, similar to those you would wear hiking (wool or wicking). Wear supportive clothing, a good sports bra & bring water. 

Kangoo Rental Sizes:

Small - Womens 4-6 or Mens 3-5
Medium - Womens 6-9 Mens 6-8
Large - Womens 10-12 Mens 9-11
XLarge - Womens 12+, Mens 12-15

Action Required After RSVP: 
Please add your Kangoo size to the comments board so that I can arrange to have them onsite for the class.

Communications:
I'll arrive on site early and will use the meetup board to communicate. I'll send my contact info to those that RSVP. Please use text when contacting me if poss.


Misc but Important:
- Please don't video tape anyone the without their consent, pics are fine

.- There is no secure place to put your things, open lockers are right by the front door so leave your valuables in car or at home.

 - Bring cash/exact change (if possible) to expedite - Bring a healthy snack with you for the ride home.

- Zumba class lets out prior to the Kangoo classes, there may not be much room to in the foyer to wait around for Zuma to end. I like to wait until the Zuma class exits the building before entering.

- You can not just show up at this event without an RSVP. Kangoos are brought to the location based on your RSVP & size + class size must be controlled due to type of activity. 

Prereqs:
Anyone with basic concepts of aerobics, step, boxing or zumba/dance and enjoys a high intensity cardio workout.

* Future Kangoo Jump Events:

results.description:
Ellen Jaffe JonesThe Veg Coach

Creative Cook / Author / Consultant
From our test kitchen to your home kitchen

OK, show of hands.  How many of you eat quinoa as a side dish?
Most cooks use the protein-rich grain as a substitute for rice.
But, I've got a treat for you today.  It's a recipe for Quinoa crisp chocolate balls!
What a way to reward yourself for following a healthy lifestyle.

Find it below.

Consider this too as a tasty approach to getting people interested in coming to one of my FREE cooking classes. This week, Wednesday at 9pm EST, I'll be doing a free class prepping and serving 2 recipes from my book "Eat Vegan on $4 a Day." Bring any questions to our Google Hangout: 

https://plus.google.com/events/c0oegddjuh07utbrq1mv6vm1rfg

Happy cooking,

Ellen Jaffe Jones
The Veg Coach
http://www.vegcoach.com

Buy my books:

Paleo Vegan

Eat Vegan on $4 a Day

Kitchen Divided - Vegan Recipes for Semi-Vegan Households

This is a Quinoa crisp chocolate bar you might find at your local health food store.  
But, my recipe lets you create your own Quinoa chocolate treat.  

It'll satisfy your chocolate cravings and it's so easy to make.  

The recipe is below.

You're Going to Love This!  

Quinoa Crisp Chocolate Treats
by Ellen Jaffe Jones

INGREDIENTS 

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

PREPARATION INSTRUCTIONS

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

Melt chocolate chips in a double-boiler, or place in a microwave-safe bowl and heat for about 60 seconds until the chips develop a slight sheen.  
Place all ingredients in a medium pot (or add to the double-boiler) and over medium heat, and stir constantly for about 5 minutes taking care not to burn the chocolate. 
Form small balls and place on a non-stick cookie sheet.  
Refrigerate for at least 60 minutes before serving.  
For those wanting to reduce fat intake, this can be made without the coconut oil, but make sure the chocolate chips are completely melted.

Surely, this merely scratches the surface.

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
Note revised location: BioLabs Lecture Hall, 16 Divinity Ave., Cambridge. - S. 

Novel climate-Novel Ecosystems: Effects of directional changes in precipitation amount and variability ... with Osvaldo Sala, Julie A. Wrigley Chair and Foundation Professor, School of Life Sciences and School of Sustainability, Arizona State University

Details forthcoming - Part of the Harvard University Center for the Environment (HUCE) seminar series - Ecological Systems in the Anthropocene

This event is free and open to the public. Event link HERE. Reception to follow. Details below. 

Thursday, April 21st, - Check time! - S.

BioLabs Lecture Hall, 16 Divinity Ave., Cambridge

:: :: ::

The Ecological Systems in the Anthropocene series will examine the future of social-environmental systems in a globe heavily impacted by humans. Each year the series will present a set of speakers and events (e.g., seminars, panels, debates) focused on one perspective under this theme. The theme for the first year is "Novel ecosystems, novel climates: Is today’s environment unprecedented?" This series is hosted by HUCE and organized by Elizabeth Wolkovich, Assistant Professor of Organismic and Evolutionary Biology.

:: :: ::

Since the retreat of glaciers poleward over 10,000 years ago, humans have left an ever increasing fingerprint on ecological systems across the globe. The environment is now dominated by people—approximately 1/3 of land area has been transformed for human use and 1/4 of global productivity diverted to human consumption. While concepts such as wilderness attempt to escape this reality, there is virtually no habitat on earth devoid of some sign of humans influence on the globe—be it chemical, thermal, or a missing or introduced species. Today, this imprint is so pronounced that scientists are actively debating naming a new geological epoch demarcated by the sign of humans on the earth system itself: the Anthropocene.

In the shadow of this debate, the HUCE seminar series "Ecological Systems in the Anthropocene" will examine the future of social-environmental systems in a globe heavily impacted by humans. Each year the series will present a set of speakers and events (e.g., seminars, panels, debates) focused on one perspective under this theme.

The theme for the first year is "Novel ecosystems, novel climates: Is today’s environment unprecedented?"

Future years' themes will cover: ‘Will the sixth mass extinction ever end? Human imprints on the tree of life,’ ‘The future of engineered ecosystems: Crops’ and ‘The Anthropocene as the Homogene: Disease, invasive species and globalization’

:: :: ::

SPRING SEMESTER SCHEDULE

Wednesday, February 3 - 4pm - "Uncharted Waters: Novel ecosystems in the marine environment"

Thursday, March 31: Stephen Jackson, Director of Southwest Climate Science Center, "Ecological novelty, old and new: conservation in a post-normal world." Details forthcoming

Thursday, April 21: Osvaldo Sala, Julie A. Wrigley Chair and Foundation Professor, School of Life Sciences and School of Sustainability, Arizona State University, "Novel climate-Novel Ecosystems: Effects of directional changes in precipitation amount and variability." Details forthcoming

:: :: ::

Contact: Laura Hanrahan, Communications CoordinatorHarvard University Center for the Environment24 Oxford Street, Cambridge, [masked] | p:[masked]
results.name: Novel Ecosystems (BioLabs)

Synopsis:

Green Room is a brilliantly crafted and wickedly fun horror-thriller starring Patrick Stewart as a diabolical club owner who squares off against an unsuspecting but resilient young punk band. Down on their luck punk rockers The Ain’t Rights are finishing up a long and unsuccessful tour, and are about to call it quits when they get an unexpected booking at an isolated, run-down club deep in the backwoods of Oregon. What seems merely to be a third-rate gig escalates into something much more sinister when they witness an act of violence backstage that they weren’t meant to see. Now trapped backstage, they must face off against the club’s depraved owner, Darcy Banker (Stewart), a man who will do anything to protect the secrets of his nefarious enterprise. But while Darcy and his henchmen think the band will be easy to get rid of, The Ain’t Rights prove themselves much more cunning and capable than anyone expected, turning the tables on their unsuspecting captors and setting the stage for the ultimate life-or-death showdown.

results.description:
LOCATION UPDATE

Cambridge Courtyard
Charles River Room, 2nd Floor
777 Memorial Drive
Cambridge, MA

Sponsored by BA Insight

This session is designed to give you a clear understanding of an exciting new capability from Microsoft called Cloud Hybrid search, which became GA in March 2016.  The discussion will cover how it can be used to bring external content into Office 365, and how to make hybrid O365/on-prem configurations successful by using search to bridge content silos.  The core on-prem component of it, the Cloud SSA, is available in SharePoint 2016 and in SharePoint 2013.

• Tour the new Cloud Hybrid Search capability; understand how it works, its benefits, and its limitations.  

• Learn how to apply it in common scenarios and how to address data residency, security, and quality concerns.Learn how to bring essential external content into the Office 365 index, and how to light up Delve, DLP, and other online experiences with content from a wide variety of sources.  We walk through several case studies and show how to take advantage of this capability from Office 365 and from SharePoint on-prem - including SharePoint 2010.

• Understand the scaling, performance, and security characteristics; how to plan and execute a successful deployment; and how to use Cloud Hybrid Search to make migration simpler.

• See how to apply the Cloud SSA even if you have a "pure cloud" configuration with no SharePoint on-prem.

Presented by Mike Gregory

​Mike is the Director of Systems Engineering for BA Insight. He works closely with sales teams to evaluate the business challenges prospective customers and partners face with the implementation of SharePoint portals within different environments. He determines how the BA Insight Software Portfolio will help them improve these implementations and enterprise search across their organizations. This evaluation process often includes technical discussions, demonstrations, and targeted proofs of concepts.​

During his more than 25 years of experience in Enterprise Software, Mike has advised hundreds of Fortune 1000 companies and government agencies around the world, advancing their IT strategies and infrastructure. He has expertise in a wide variety of application areas including Enterprise Search, Knowledge Management, Enterprise Learning, Content Management, CRM, Call Center Management, and Human Resources.
results.name: Using Cloud Hybrid Search with Office 365

We are giving away $500 in Amazon Gift cards thanks to our friends at Grasshopper! 

We're excited to bring you April's Board Game Night, as always hosted by East Coast Product, and this month sponsored by Localytics, OpenView, Ipswich Ale Brewery, Grasshopper, and Gatsby Social.

Your $5 registration includes drinks and snacks. All proceeds benefit the ever awesome Resilient Coders, an organization dedicated to making web tech education more accessible to urban youth. Localytics is also matching all of your donations so your $5 goes a lot further. 

Half-networking, half-gaming -- it's the only event in Boston that brings together innovation enthusiasts for an evening of friendly competition and great conversation. Don't forget to spread the word use the hashtag #BGN11 and tweet us @BGNio to stay in the loop and build our community.

East Coast Product is a digital product agency that helps organizations get to their next strategic milestone. We work with clients through the entire software development process, from strategy to design to execution, resulting in exceptional product delivery. We develop products with the users in mind and a focus on understanding the why's that go into successful products. PWL Boston / Cambridge 

We are thrilled to have Peter Bailis as the speaker for our April meeting.  Peter is brilliant researcher and outstanding speaker.  He will be presenting on Streaming Queries over Streaming Data" from VLDB 2002 by Sirish Chandrasekaran and Michael J. Franklin. 

If you are looking for a preview of the type of talks Peter gives, check out this talk given at the PWL SF chapter in late 2014 on Bayou

Bio

After spending this year visiting MIT CSAIL, Peter Bailis will join Stanford Computer Science as an assistant professor. Peter's research in the Future Data Systems group (http://futuredata.stanford.edu) focuses on the design and implementation of next-generation data-intensive systems. His work spans novel distributed protocol design, large-scale data management, and architectures for high-volume complex decision support. He is the recipient of a NSF Graduate Research Fellowship, a Berkeley Fellowship for Graduate Study, best-of-conference citations for research appearing in SIGMOD and VLDB, and a CRA Outstanding Undergraduate Researcher Award. He received a Ph.D. in Computer Science from UC Berkeley in 2015 and an A.B. from Harvard College in 2011.


Logistics 

PWL Boston / Cambridge is hosted at the Battery Ventures office in the Seaport: 

One Marina Park Drive, FL 11

Boston, MA 02210

Upon arriving at One Marina Park Drive, you will need your IDs to check in with security in the lobby. You will then be directed to the 11th floor.

Parking is available in the garage at One Marina Park Drive for a cost of $15, if you enter after 5:00 p.m. There are also 2 open lots at 50 & 85 Northern Ave, as well as metered street parking. The building is walkable from the Courthouse stop on the Silver Line and South Station.

Agenda 

6-6.30 – Mingle / Eat

6.30 - 7.30 - Talk 

7.30- 8.00 - Q&A 

8.00  - Adjourn

While not an operating system in the traditional sense, ROS (Robot Operating System) is a set of open-source libraries and tools underpinning much of the software development on modern robotic platforms. In its roughly 8 years of existence, it has transformed itself from a little known tool to a near ubiquitous development platform. This meetup hopes to provide a little bit of something for everyone:

• An introduction to basic ROS concepts for beginners - Katy Powers and Ian McMahon of Rethink Robotics


• An overview of Adaptive Monte Carlo Localization and the AMCL package - Alex Sher of Vecna Technologies   


• And as always, a forum to stand up and advertise job openings, introduce yourself, or propose anything else you'd like to discuss

MVVM is one of the favorite patterns among developers for building and architecting amazing mobile applications. Xamarin.Forms allows you to build native UIs for iOS, Android, and Windows in XAML. Because Xamarin.Forms supports data binding and other MVVM functionalities out-of-the-box, it's easier than ever to build stunning views that automatically are synchronized with changes to the underlying data source.

In this talk by Xamarin Developer Evangelist Nish Anil, we will explore the basics of the MVVM pattern, how to reuse your existing View Models in Xamarin.Forms, and learn to leverage them in Xamarin.Forms controls and pages.

results.description:
Hello Boston Node.JS & Javascript Community!

Thanks to all of you that attended the March meetup at Fitbit. We exceeded our turnout from the February meetup, with more Node/JS enthusiasts than ever!  I will be posting more pictures from that meetup soon, and I'm trying to obtain all of the slides to post to this site.

In case you all missed the announcement from a few weeks ago, Node.JS in the Wild and Node.JS Boston have merged!  We will be continuing forward under the umbrella of Node.JS Boston with Freedom, Jesse, Tim, Dan and myself co-organizing all future events.  We have a lot of ideas and things in progress and will try to keep you all informed if we need help or ideas going forward.  As always, please forward all ideas and messages to one of us and we will try to accommodate!  Our goal is to try and create a fun and educational space within the Node and Javascript community in Boston - where we can exchange ideas, present information about our works in progress and most importantly, have fun.


In the spirit of continuing our monthly meetings, I am announcing the April meetup to be held on Thursday the 21st of April at Autodesk's new HQ on Drydock Ave in Boston's Seaport district.  Autodesk will be providing food and drinks (and a really amazing new office space you really need to check out).

As always, we have an amazing lineup of speakers for this next event, check out the details below and let me know if you have any questions or feedback. I hope to see you all in a few weeks!

Brian

-------------

Jaime Rosales

3D Web powered by NodeJS

Jaime Rosales, DevTech Engineer at Autodesk, will show us a few examples of 3D on the web and take you through a demo of the Autodesk View & Data API, a WebGL-based technology that enables your website users to visualize and interact with stunning high-fidelity 3D & 2D models in a browser or on a mobile device anytime, anywhere. 

The demo will include how to get started very quickly with the technology to add 3D to your own website and a presentation of the existing Node.js samples that we created ( https://developer.autodesk.com/api/view-and-data-api/ ).

We will cover View & Data API workflows from a technical perspective targeted to Node developers using custom npm packages and tools we created to alleviate common tasks such as uploading large files, model translation, storage, and a taste of the coolest client-side JavaScript samples that we have so far.

Bio: Jaime Rosales (@afrojme) is a DevTech Engineer at Autodesk, who has promoted many of the company's Web services technologies over the past 2 years. View & Data API being the most attractive one to the JS community. Actively, he spends part of his time presenting in different parts of the US, big cities like NYC, Texas, Florida, Minnesota, Chicago, San Francisco and Silicon Valley being some of the main ones, about the implementation of 3D content for web apps. He was in the Speakers line-up for last year JS Conference in Medellin, Colombia . He is part of the well-known group of developers from the AEC & VR Hackathons that occur around the world.


Gregor Martynus 

Small Modules FTW: Automate npm releases and dependency updates

Small modules is the success story of npm: there are 250,000 packages today. It’s like lego, all the bricks are there, we just need to assemble them, barely do we need to create new ones.

But: small modules come with big overheads. They say.

I say: challenge accepted!

In this talk, I’ll show 

1. how to automise the entire release process for your npm modules with [semantic-release](https://www.npmjs.com/package/semantic-release),  and

2. how to make make sure that all your dependencies are up-to-date, all the time, with [greenkeeper.io](http://greenkeeper.io)

And all it takes fits on a single slide. 

About Me: I’m part of the [Hoodie](hood.ie) community. We started things like [noBackend](http://nobackend.org/) and [Offline First](http://hood.ie/blog/say-hello-to-offline-first.html). For our upcoming release of Hoodie, we decide to focus on lowering the barriers and overhead for contributors and maintainers, and as a result created Semantic Release and Greenkeeper, which I don’t want to miss in any of my Node work any more.

Ian Spiro

Make the commitment to safer apps with Nodejs security

NodeJS frameworks offer a great foundation to build high throughput and extremely performant applications with minimal friction. However, rapid design and implementation has brought with it an increased ability to deploy insecure code. Within this past year we have witnessed many high-profile security breaches. It's time to make a change to the way we think about security. In this talk, we will discover:

- The critical need for secure nodeJS

- Introspection into what has stalled the adoption of secure coding practices

- Real life examples of insecure code and mitigation.

- Explore vulnerable code specific to scaling up nodeJS apps

Bio: Ian still retains characteristics indicative of his misspent youth as a professional snowboarder for Burton Snowboards as part of the Burton Global A Team. He graduated magna cum laude from the University of Vermont in 2005, with a B.S. in Computer Science and a B.S. in Applied Mathematics. He spent eight years at Ounce Labs/IBM helping to develop one of the industry’s leading static analysis tools, performing hundreds of security assessments of high-risk enterprise applications, and prototyping new methodologies for understanding web application frameworks. In 2013, Ian founded Vermont Secure Computing, where he designed and developed new security technologies for cryptocurrencies and cryptographic key management.

Barry will introduce us to the primary evidence that as quantum physics explains, consciousness creates the brain, and the brain does not create consciousness as previously believed. The presentation will be more "good news" that we have been "Beggars At God's Banquet," unaware we are creators, and thus unaware of our incredible powers.
About Barry:

Barry Harris majored in quantum physics in college, attended a “New Universe” workshop taught by David Bohm (one of the most significant theoretical physicists of the 20th century), and Karl Pribram (who showed the brain as the decoder of holograms), and took a weeklong course with Karl Pribram’s graduate student assistant.

Barry also worked at the Hippocrates Institute in Boston, writing health booklets for Dr. Ann Wigmore, discoverer of wheatgrass and founder of the live food movement. Hippocrates Institute is a unique healing center with a powerful spiritual focus, and an extreme dietary regime which often attracted clients who Western medicine had labeled terminally ill. While there Barry witnessed many miraculous recoveries.

Later Barry witnessed more miracles while working for four years in various centers around the U.S. founded by Viktoras Kulvinskas, Dr. Wigmore's Director. Obsessed with the secret to miracles, Barry did 20 years of independent research connecting quantum physics to Energy Medicine, cellular biology, neurophysiology, mind/body medicine, effect of emotions on health, etc.

Barry's research has been the source for the course "Beggars At God's Banquet: Miracles Are Our Birthright" which he has been presenting for the past nine years. Barry's book "Beggars At God's Banquet" based on the contents of the course will be published by X-Libris Publishing in the spring.

Barry is also a singer/voice teacher who teaches "Voice as a Path of Spiritual and Emotional Healing". His voice students learn the relationship of ego to breath patterns, and how to surrender control to a higher power. Barry is qualified to teach about miracles, because he had his own miracle. He restored his singing voice by recognizing the need for spiritual grace and surrender of control to a higher power, after Western doctors said he had damaged his voice beyond repair.

Barry can be reached at [masked].

results.description:
Are you curious about programming or thinking about pursuing a career in software engineering? 

Then RSVP on this meet-up page for this 2-hour Intro to Coding class happening in the Boston area at CIC Boston. Learn the basics of programming, do hands-on exercises, and meet new people. All for free!

The class is being taught by MakerSquare, which runs some of the top coding schools in the country.

Class officially starts at 6:30pm, but please arrive at CIC Boston by 6:15pm to mingle with your fellow classmates and settle in. We will end at 9pm, with the last 30 minutes being an optional Q&A session.

What will I learn during the class?

This beginner ­level class will contain several instructor-guided exercises. The class will cover the following topics:

   1. Overview of programming 

   2. Intro to data & data structures

   3. Basics of functions

We ask that you read the Prerequisites section before the start of class and bring your own laptop (Windows, Mac or Linux) with Google Chrome installed.

What is MakerSquare Boston?

MakerSquare is a three-month full-time school for software engineering. By teaching computer science fundamentals and modern web languages like JavaScript, we prepare students to join top flight engineering teams.

We have campuses all over the country, and are excited to be opening a campus in Boston. The free Intro to Coding class is to introduce more people to the wonderful world of programming and to get the community excited about the launch of our full-time class in Boston in July 2016!

Questions? Email us at [masked].
results.name: Free Intro to Coding Class (Thurs April 21, 6:30-9pm)

Every Thursday evening at 6:30 PM we gather as a group for a nice nighttime "romp" at the Chestnut Hill Reservoir. It's a great way to wind down a busy work day, to catch up with Bulldogs friends, or to meet new people!

The Boston Bulldogs is a co-ed non-profit running club founded to support those battling addiction and in recovery, those who have been affected by addiction and their supporters.

We welcome and encourage runners of all levels – dreamers, beginners, as well as those with running experience, past or present. Our volunteer runners will be there to coach you at your current level, and help you meet your goals. We might even be able to help with running gear if needed. 

We meet twice weekly at the Reservoir (Cleveland Circle/Reservoir Green Line C or D train) -- on Saturday mornings at 10:00 am and Thursday evenings at 6:30 pm. We will first gather in front of the Starbucks in Cleveland Circle, before heading over to the reservoir. See you there! 

If you are interested in becoming a member or a volunteer, in making a contribution to the Club, in sponsoring a runner in recovery, or in learning more about the Boston Bulldog educational wellness/running program, contact us at:

• Website - BostonBulldogsRunning.com

• Email - [masked] 

• Phone -[masked]

results.description:
Free. Fun. Starts here!

Welcome to the Dedham Couch to 5K sponsored by St. Luke's Lutheran Church. We love people the Dedham area and want to help them in any way we can. 

We have 2 groups: 

Our Walking Group will exercise and encourage one another towards walking a 5K. 

Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K.

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace. 

• FREE 9-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners 

• Monday through Thursdays 6:30pm-7:15pm; Saturday 10:00 am-10:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week 

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Pack the Pantry 5K on June 11
results.name: Dedham Couch to 5K—Spring 2016

results.description:
Please RSVP for this game so we know we have enough people. We'll confirm by 3pm or earlier that the game is on.


6:30-6:45 pm - Warm up & practice, we'll work on some throws, passes & catches.

6:45 pm - Game starts.

General guidelines: Dress accordingly. Bring a white & dark shirt so we can easily divide into 2 teams. Have plenty of water. Sunscreen on a sunny day. Stretch & warm up. We'll provide discs and cones.

Weather: Rain in New England is unpredictable. We will send out a final notice one hour before start time if cancellation is necessary.

RSVP: Very helpful as this is how we contact you in case of game changes & cancellations.

About: Playing Ultimate is all about good sportsmanship, respect, and gracefulness on the field.  Fun & having a good time is a must above anything else. It's an easy game to pick up & we keep the rules minimal. No zones, no stall count, no scores, and players self-officiate on the field.  Open to all levels of players.  Beginners welcome.

Warning: Excessive fun & comradery developed from playing Ultimate may become addicting.

For more information go to  http://www.cfa.harvard.edu/events or call 617.495.7461.


The CfA would prefer that attendees not take pictures, but if you decide to, please do not use a flash.

******************************

From the CfA:


Watch It Live

The Wild West of Star Formation Cara Battersby, CfA

Tonight we saddle up to explore the extreme center of our Milky Way galaxy - one of the wildest sections of the outer-space frontier. Our Galactic center is a chaotic region containing dense gas, stars, and the biggest bully around these parts: a supermassive black hole. The normal rules for star formation don't apply here, and understanding why will help us to understand star formation throughout the rest of our wild universe.


******************************

NOTE: if anyone would like to be an assistant organizer to help run various* events please contact me - Heather

*various = various science and nerdy events around town, and NOT the ones that only market your own event/product.  (SPAM=no)

Please RSVP truthfully. 

If you end up on the waiting list and you REALLY like the topic you can show up anyways as this is a public event.

Thanks!

H

results.description:
This monthly Meetup is a place to learn tunes and to play them slowly with other musicians. The tunes we play can be found here (Sheet Music). Since the list is getting large we have started selecting a rotating list of about ten tunes a month that we will definitely play so that new members can have a chance to play along without learning every tune right away. I update this list and email it monthly.

This is still a new group, and how we go about learning and playing is still a work in progress. But the goal is to have fun, and to get together with others who enjoy playing Irish music. Musicians of all levels are welcome. Since the goal here is for everyone to play, new members are encouraged to suggest tunes from the list and to suggest tunes to add to it. If the group as a whole knows a tune well, we'll play it slowly a couple of times, and then pick the tempo up a bit. 

Note on tempo

If you have gone to a typical Irish Session, we play a little faster than half that speed. But we'll start tunes slowly enough that everyone should be able to play along and learn by ear. If you haven't been to a session it is best to just show up and see if the tempo suits you :)  If you like metronomes...  For Reels (4/4), Hornpipes (4/4) and Polkas (2/4) set the metronome from 100 to 140 BPM and play one quarter note per click. For Double Jigs (6/8), Slip Jigs (9/8), and Single Jigs (12/8) set the metronome from 65 to 95 BPM and play three eighth notes per click. 

Directions

By Subway

The closest Red Line stop is Davis Square. From Davis Square you can either walk Northwest on Holland Street or take the bus (the 87 or the 88) to Teele Square. It is about a 10 minute walk between Davis and Teele Square. You can recognize Teele Square as a 5-way intersection with a small triangular island having a sign that says Teele Square. From Teele Square walk North on Curtiss Street for 3 blocks to Powder House Boulevard. The church is on the NE corner of the intersection.

By Bus

The 87, 88, and 89 buses stop in Teele Square.  The 87 bus runs between Lechmere Station (Green Line) and Arlington Center. The 88 bus runs between Lechmere Station (Green Line) and the Clarendon Hill Busway. The 89 bus runs between Sullivan Square (Orange Line) and the Clarendon Hill Busway. You'll want to get off the bus in Teele Square. From Teele Square walk North on Curtiss Street for 3 blocks to Powder House Boulevard. The church is on the NE corner of the intersection. The 77 bus runs between Harvard and Arlington Heights. You can walk from Mass Ave to Teele Square.

By Car

There is parking behind the West Somerville School that is one block West of the church. Parking there is available after 5PM even though the signs are somewhat ambiguous. From Powderhouse, turn onto Curtis, heading up the hill toward Tufts. Take the first left turn from Curtis onto Raymond Street. Ignore the NO LEFT TURN sign, as it is only in effect during rush hours. Raymond runs behind the school. The lot is about half a block down Raymond on the left.

Street parking is also available one block away on Packard Avenue from Powderhouse Blvd on the hill to the Tufts University campus. Pay attention to street signs to avoid parking in a restricted area.

See the map at: http://clarendonhillchurch.org/...

Accessibility

The church has a lift that requires someone to move from a wheelchair to the chair on the lift. I haven't had time to look at this yet, but I will have someone show it to me over the holidays.

results.description:
Crossroads Irish Pub (Boston,  Beacon St and Mass Ave intersection) 7 pm to 10 pm

Due to requests and great turnout, Japanese Evening Table is going back to Crossroads! Grab a few drinks and some delicious cheap bar food. Whether you're learning Japanese or English, buy a drink, join the table, and practice your new language in a friendly and relaxed environment. If you're a beginner or just interested in culture, you'll fit in fine! Don't miss out on this opportunity to learn and practice over a few drinks. Can't make it on time? Need to leave early? Not a problem. Just stop by if you can!

If you are >21 and plan to drink, please bring a MA state issued ID or passport. Other state IDs may not be accepted. Please order at the bar and take care of your own tab.

Transportation: I highly recommend using public transportation. Not only is driving while intoxicated dangerous, but there may not be any parking available in the area. A lot of the parking in the area is Residential Only in the evenings, and many of the signs indicating this are very well hidden. Also, watch out for those hidden street cleaning signs! If you insist on parking in the area, be aware that meter maids love handing out parking tickets around here. Best methods for public transportation are the green line subway to Hynes or bus #1 to stop between Beacon and Marlborough.

Ordering at Crossroads: 

1) Order all your drinks and food at the bar. 

2) Start a tab (付け) or pay as you go. Don't forget to tip. 

See you there!
~Lindsay

results.description:
Deepening into the practice of Speaking Circle turns will support you in continuing  to develop full presence in front of groups.  Being in Relational Presence with your audience is the key.

Relational Presence, the foundation of Speaking Circles, is a precondition for all masterful communication. When this state becomes your default mode of approaching every communication, you effortlessly step into a natural flow. 

Developing your capacity for Relational Presence is like strengthening a muscle that has been neglected. Unlike the struggle that physical workouts are for many, this exercise is designed to be highly pleasurable. There may be some initial confusion, discomfort, self-doubt but hang in there and do the reps no matter how it feels or what you are thinking.  With practice you will find . . . 

* Speaking Circles support you to access your natural public presence, along with your capacity to unselfconsciously express passion and purpose.

* Reach hearts, minds and souls every time through the practice of being in a Speaking Circle.

* Transmit your message and content with ease to groups of any size by practicing attunement with one listener at a time.

* Give up conventional notions of "public speaking" and discover the magic of authentic intimacy with audiences.
results.name: Deepening into Speaking From Presence

results.description:
It's another PGN game night!  Come have some fun with other personal growth seekers while we play Better Me: The Game of Growth. 

Last month HBS MetroWest hosted a unique and fun evening of personal growth exploring. A bunch of great folks gathered together to play a board game called Better Me. 

We heard it was a lot of fun and such a great evening for getting to know yourself and each other, building community together. 

So we're bringing PGN game night to HBS MetroCharles in Somerville this month!

If you missed it in Natick or you want to come play again, come join us!

To Prepare:

One key rule of the game is that each player must contribute a gift.  This can be anything from an “I owe you” written on a napkin, to food, an experience, a gift certificate, act of service, lessons, flowers, or whatever else you can imagine.  Every player also receives a gift at the end of the game. So think about what you might want to offer, and if it's something tangible, bring it with you.

Before you come, you can also preview the rules and/or watch this demo video.  The more people who are familiar with the game, the more time we'll be able to spend actually playing. :)


Feel free to bring friends.  It will be a great evening!

Testimonials for Better Me:

• "It was a total blast! It was fun, inspiring, motivating. Not only did I have a good time, but I walked away with some things I know I need to work on in my own life."  -Robb Gorringe, Seattle, USA

• "This is one of the most unique board games I have played and it allowed me to get to know total strangers on a deep level in a matter of minutes."  -Stephen Y, San Francisco, USA

• "Love the game! Good way to get to know each other. Things you normally don't talk about that often (but should), you get to work on now."  -Daniel Stegehuis, Holland

• "I would highly recommend playing Better Me if you are open minded and want to surround yourself with positive, open minded people as well as become a better version of you, while having fun!"
 -Johnny FD, San Francisco, USA TravelLikeABossPodcast.com

• "Better Me is the most memorable board game I have ever played and also the most enjoyable." -Russell Smith, Chandler's Ford, England

results.description:
"A universal theology is impossible, but a universal experience is not only possible but necessary. It is this experience toward which the course is directed." (ACIM Manual for Teachers)

Designed to correct perception and lead to a universal experience of knowledge, A Course In Miracles has been translated into 23 languages, is referenced and utilized by many of today's most reknowned spiritual teachers, and has inspired countless books and curriculums based on its teachings. But it can be a difficult book to grasp. It is lengthy, the writing is abstract, and its use of Christian terminology alienates many.

And yet it has become one of the most influential spiritual books of today. Join us as we dive into it, and are led to understand its principles against the backdrop of our own questions, personal experiences, and realizations. Beginner as well as advanced Course students are welcome. We'll start with a short meditation, and then use a reading from the Course as an entry point into our time together. Cost $5 per person.

Bringing a copy of the book is helpful, but not necessary. Recommended (but again not necessary) is the combined volume that includes the three supplements (Clarification of Terms; Psychotherapy: Purpose, Process, and Practice; The Song of Prayer), available online from The Foundation For Inner Peace at acim.org.
results.how_to_find_us: From Concord St.: we're 4/10th's of a mile down Russell St. on the right, the driveway after Fraser Farm.
results.name: Join us as we discuss A Course In Miracles and apply its principles to our lives

results.description:
Presentation Abstract

=====================

Jenkins Job DSL offers a means to manage Jenkins through Groovy code in a fully repeatable, automated manner. In this demonstration, we'll start with a completely blank Jenkins instance, and use Job DSL to accomplish a number of basic tasks such as:


1) Creating and running a "Hello, World!" job on a schedule


2) Building all branches of a Java project using Maven on checkin


3) Chaining multiple dynamically generated jobs together to create a workflows


4) Driving Job DSL with an external source of jobs via an API integration

Bio Don Luchini
===========
Currently a Senior Software Engineer at EnerNOC, Inc. here in Boston, I have a very varied background which gives me a unique perspective to DevOps. Within the last ten years, I've successively been employed as a Web designer, sysadmin, embedded software developer, QA engineer, and release engineer. My current job primarily consists of creating build lifecycle workflows which enable developers to rapidly deploy and test in local-, datacenter-, and cloud-based environments. I've been a consumer of Jenkins for roughly five years, and a Jenkins administrator for roughly three.
results.name: Overview of Jenkins Job DSL with Don Luchini

http://gotsunset.eventbrite.com/?aff=mu


Sip on the Seven Kingdoms Hoppy Wheat Beer, my sweet summer child. It's delicious and refreshing just like lands of the south. But don't forget, Winter is Coming (well, hopefully it's gone for now!), so try Take the Black Stout, a Belgian stout made with star anise and licorice. 

As dark as the Black Cells beneath King's Landing, Shadow Brewer Imperial Stout is an impressive 9.7% Imperial Stout that tastes of malt, coffee and chocolate!

They'll be serving some fantastic beers.

Don't forget to RSVP here to save your spot!

Our eleventh annual artistic nude shoot will take place on Thursday evening, April 21.  Shooting will go from 7:30-9:30 pm but everybody will need to arrive by 7:00 pm for an orientation meeting and to help set up for the shoot.  All photographers who can arrive by 6:30 pm to start setting up, please do!

Our models*:  Evie Cherrie Louise MM[masked], Briella Jaden MM[masked], CAArtistic MM[masked]   *as always,  subject to change. 

The cost of this shoot will be $95 for photographers who are paid RiversEdge members and $115 for other photographers.  Sign-ups will be accepted on a first-come, first-served basis up to our maximum capacity of 9 photographers.  You can pay by cash or check at a meeting, or you can use the PayPal buttons on our payments page.  We are planning to have a photographer:model ratio no worse than 3:1.

The final deadline for signing up and paying is April 14 (the date of our April workshop meeting).  We will not be able to give refunds unless the event is canceled.

Please note that RSVPing here for this meetup does not sign you up for the shoot.  You will be considered signed up for the shoot only when your payment has been received.  RSVPs that are not accompanied by payment will eventually be removed.

results.description:
Join us to eat, drink, write, share work, trade author/book recommendations, and more!

Thursday Format:
After a round of introductions, we start out with a general, unstructured freewrite to get everyone in the writing mindset. We continue writing to a series of three or so writing prompts that usually one of the organizers has prepared before hand. Members are encouraged to share their work, or what they wrote about, for each prompt. We spend the remainder of the group working on our own separate projects, continuing work from one of the prompts, freewriting, or just chatting with each other.

When we have a piece to workshop, we often will write to two or so prompts, and then will go into a discussion of that piece. The workshop may take up the rest of the group, or may conclude with time left at the end.


Read more about workshops here.

results.name: Let's continue the creative fun of our past meetups!

results.description:
Ongoing class in Medieval and Renaissance Longsword in the tradition of Johannes Lichtenauer.


The Longsword is the iconic fantasy Knight's sword - a two-handed, straight blade with a cross guard. The weapon may seem to be simple at first but is in reality a weapon of finesse and skill.


The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed.


All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.
results.name: Lichtenauer Longsword

We're bringing this awesome event to Boston for the first time! Get a chance to meet with 20+ investors, engage with investors on two panels on VC and investing, 2 Lightning Rounds, and a Venture Fair where you get a chance for some 1:1 with the investors there.

We'll have over twenty awesome Venture Capital (VC) and Angel Investors there answering your questions on what is VC, the process for getting VC, what investors look for, and more. Plus a chance to tell your story and meet with some of the investors 1:1.

PRESENTED BY DLA Piper

DLA Piper is a global law firm with 4,200 lawyers in the Americas, Asia Pacific, Europe and the Middle East, positioning us to help companies with their legal needs around the world. We strive to be the leading global business law firm by delivering quality and value to our clients. We achieve this through practical and innovative legal solutions that help our clients succeed. We deliver consistent services across our platform of practices and sectors in all matters we undertake.

Agenda & Schedule

08:00 - 08:20  ::  Registration and Networking

08:20 - 08:30  ::  Welcomes

VC Panel #1 - "Seed and Series A Financing" + Ask Me Anything
The first panel will be a VC 101 panel focused on Early State Financing, moderated by Ronald Schmelzer, focusing on the following topics:

What does your firm invest in and focus on?How do you even begin talking to a VC?What's the process like for soliciting, interacting with, and getting investment from VCsPLUS YOUR questions in "Ask Me Anything" style

VC Panel #2 - "Emerging Trends in VC" + Ask Me Anything
The second panel will be with additional investors identifying emerging trends in Venture Capital and investing, moderated by Ronald Schmelzer, focusing on the following topics:

What are the latest hot areas for investors?What's big in the NY region?What's changing in the way companies are getting funded?PLUS YOUR questions in "Ask Me Anything" style

TWO 20 minute Lightning Rounds:
Your Chance to Have Everyone Hear Your Story!
 Each Lightning Round will consist of five randomly selected participants who have elected to participate in a public embarrassment, er, I mean public feedback. They will get 1 minute (timed) to do an Elevator Pitch with no slides and no supporting material, plus 4 minutes of questions and feedback from the the full panel. For this event, we'll be running two of these Lightning Rounds in front of different panels so we'll maximize the fun and randomness.

results.description:
This walk is on a paved path through the woods. This path is stroller friendly or you could carry your child. It is a little hilly, but appropriate for most fitness levels. We alternate walks between the inner and outer loops which are both under 3 miles. It usually takes less than an hour. We walk past a playground too, so we could stop and play there for a while. Afterwards, we sit at the picnic tables under the trees by the visitor center and feed our babies, chat, etc. 

We will meet outside the visitor center in the upper parking lot on the Saugus side of the park, past the Kasabuski Skating Rink.  There are bathrooms with a changing table in the visitor center too.

Running late?  No prob. We'll wait about 15 minutes before starting the walk.  Running really late? You can always meet up with us at the picnic tables next to the visitor center after we finish the walk.  

***By popular demand this is set as weekly event.  If the weather is bad we can change it to a different day or skip the week.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be the group with the strollers hanging out in front of the visitor center.

results.description:
Newegg and eSports Hero have teamed up to bring you an awesome Hearthstone experience at PAX East! 

The Newegg Hearthstone Open is a 3 day event (Fri, Sat, Sun) where three 64 seat Hearthstone tournaments will be hosted in room #106. The tournaments are free to join and open to players of all skill levels. 

Signups are first come first serve and open at 10am. The format will be Conquest Best of 3 Single Elimination and will run from 11am-4pm. The tournaments will be recorded and casted by top streamers and pros. 

In addition to the tournament, there will be Hearthstone trivia, cosplayers, giveaways, and more! This event is BYOD (bring your own device).


Tons of gaming prizes & raffles: Gaming chairs, Gaming keyboards, Gaming mice, mouse pads, Hearthstone gear, Overwatch gear, Giftcards, & more. 

Newegg will also have a booth with well-known Hearthstone Pros to play against. Noxious, SuperJJ, Ryzen, and others will be there to hangout with and play against players. *Beating a HS Pro will earn you an  E-Blue mouse pad*
results.how_to_find_us: Room#106 (Also can DM @eSportHero on Twitter)
results.name: Newegg Hearthstone Tournament at PAX East!

results.description:
Are you going to the local gaming convention of PAX East? Many of us are, too! It's difficult to get a large group together at conventions, but hopefully we can use this meetup event to see who else is going, find people who want to sit together at panels, or play games together. It's a great event!

WHAT IS PAX: In 2004, the folks at Penny Arcade decided they wanted a show exclusively for gaming. Sure, comics, anime, and other nerd hobbies were cool, and those activities all had their own shows… so what about games? From that idea spawned a small 4,500 person event in Bellevue, Washington, focused on the culture and community that is gaming.

Since then, the show hasn’t looked back. Doubling in size each year until venue capacities were reached, in 2010 the show expanded into Boston for PAX East, drawing tens of thousands of attendees in the inaugural year. The shows in Seattle and Boston represent the two largest gaming events in North America!

Website: http://east.paxsite.com/
Schedule: http://east.paxsite.com/schedule

FYI : TICKETS ARE SOLD OUT
results.name: PAX East

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball.

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
The Deluxe Station Diner is located in Newton Center in the old train station building that's right at the Newton Center T stop.  It has the right balance of ambiance and good food/drinks, reasonably priced with a very comfortable feel to it; warm and friendly.  We sit at the bar if we have a small group.  We grab a table  for a larger group.

They have a number of interesting specialty drinks.  I have tried the Blueberry Lemonade and the Apple Pie.  Believe it or not, those are both vodka drinks.  They were both very good and reasonably priced.  The kind of drinks that you need to be careful with because it's easy to forget there's alcohol in them.

I'd classify the food as "comfort food".  We've had the burgers, mac & cheese, curried chicken, meatloaf, chicken pot pie, and fish & chips.  Everything has tasted great and was reasonably priced.

Several large municipal parking lots are nearby. Meters are free after 6:00 pm.

MBTA: Green Line, “D” train, Newton Center stop. When you come up the stairs from the train tracks, you are on Union Street. The diner is inside the old brownstone Union Station.

Bus #52 from Watertown Square (www.mbta.com for schedule and exact route).

Driving:

From the Mass Pike (east-bound):
Take exit 17 and make your first right after the set of lights, onto Centre Street. Follow Centre Street approximately three miles through. Take a left onto Langley Road and park in the parking lot on the left or park any where on Langley Road. (There are many other different options to park around Newton Center).

From the Mass Pike (west-bound):
Take exit 17 and go straight off the ramp. After the ramp, you will go through two sets of lights. After the second set, turn left at the sign that says "Newton Centre/Boston." You will be making a 180-degree turn and should stay in the right lane. Take your first right after the 180-degree turn onto Centre Street. Follow Centre Street approximately three miles through. Take a left onto Langley Road and park in the parking lot on the left or park any where on Langley Road. (There are many other different options to park around Newton Center).

From Route 9:
Take the Newton Center/Centre Street Exit. Follow Centre Street until you reach Beacon Street. Take a right onto Beacon Street and park in the parking lot on your left or on Beacon Street.

results.description:
Hello Kongers,

Join us for our first inaugural Kong meetup in Boston. Come network with other Kong users, meet the Kong team, and learn about Microservices & APIs.

As for presentations, we’ll be providing an overview of Kong (including the new Postgres support) and a demo of a couple of useful integrations including Galileo for API analytics, and Gelato as Developer Portal. 


Agenda: 

6:00 - Check-in & happy hour 

6:30 - Introduction of Kong 

7:00 - Galileo+Kong Demo

7:15 - Gelato+Kong Demo 

7:30 - Q&A 

Speakers: 

Augusto Marietti - CEO at Mashape

Ahmad Nassri - Head of Engineering at Mashape

-- 

We’ll have food & good drinks (beers and wine).

No matter your skill level or familiarity with APIs, all are welcome to attend.  Space is limited, so be sure to reserve your spot today. 

We look forward to meeting you in person!

--

About Kong

The open-source Microservice & API Management Layer. 

Kong was created to secure, manage and extend Microservices & APIs. Kong is powered by the battle-tested tech of NGINX with a focus on scalability, high performance & reliability.

Kong is being used in over 100 countries across the world, by developers and devops like you, working at small and big companies.
results.name: Kong API Gateway Intro + Galileo (API analytics) and Gelato (Dev Portal) demos.

results.description:
Join the second meeting of the growing HBS-Braintree as members Angela and Barbara lead us in a discussion as we get to know each other and look at how we are holding our happiness!

Our Topic This Evening We Will .... Get to Know Each Other and Enjoy Even More Happiness!!!

Tonight we will get to know each other through several conversations and discussions including but not limited to:

~Quick Intros

~Informal Discussions thru Q&A

~More In-Depth conversations bout where you are, where are you going, and what you would like to grow in

~What progress have we made since our Book Discussion of the The Happiness Project last month and where we want to go next

~How can we help you?

~Discussion of future event ideas

~Discussion of future south shore possibilities

To Prepare ....

1)  What should we know about you to help you?
2) What was your takeaway from The Happiness Project Book Discussion and what action steps have you taken?

3) What areas can we help you grow in?
4) Is there anything else you would like to discuss?

Our Leaders This Evening

This evening's leaders are Angela and Barbara.  Angela hosted and led our Discussion of The Happiness Project last month.  Barbara and Eric both attended the Discussion of The Happiness Project last month and have agreed to help us move forward with our newest HBS in Braintree.  Tonight Angela and Barbara will lead the discussions as we get to know each other.

Angela Nuss has read dozens of self-help books, including all three of Gretchen Rubin’s Happiness books.  She has implemented several strategies and will help introduce you to your own Happiness Project journey! Angela is licensed in Property & Casualty Insurance, owns her condo in Braintree, and has recently started 2 home-based businesses.  One of her many goals is to become a Money/Financial and/or Life Coach.

Angela is a positive outgoing person who continually strives to be a better, happier person and enjoys helping others immensely.  Angela has been organizing and hosting various events since she co-founded the Braintree High School Interact Club in 1993.  She received the Unsung Hero Award at Bentley College for events she organized, has hosted and organized hundreds of singles dating events, and is one of the longest-running Meetup.com organizers starting two of the first Meetup groups on the South Shore in the summer of 2006.

Barbara has been studying literature, philosophy and psychology her entire life, always working towards increasing knowledge and self awareness.  She believes everyone has the potential to change and improve their quality of life, no matter what the circumstances.  She has many years of experience working with people in the medical and mental health fields.  Her main passions include helping others, practicing yoga, reading and researching, nature, and animals.  This is her first time hosting a Meetup event, and she looks forward to seeing this group grow. 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
