results.description:
Kangoo Jumps is one of the latest fitness crazes catching on across the country.  It's an amazing workout for people who are interested in losing weight and building strength. Great for those who want a high intensity cardio workout with far less impact to their joints. Kangoo jumps can burn up to 50% more calories than traditional workouts.

                                                    Meetup Details:


Organizer/Event Host:
Jenna  (SHC)

Kangoo Jumps Instructor:
Wendel C.

Sponsored by:
Kangoo Jumps Club - MA.


Choreography Level:
Easy, basic steps, entry level

Cardio Level:
High Intensity Workout

Location:
Abington

Cost:
$15.00 with Kangoo rental - $10.00 without rental, * Special rate pricing avail to SSH&B/SHC members only.


Attendance Limit:
10 members, limit may increase as needed later.

Gear/Clothing:
Bring 2 pairs of thick socks, similar to those you would wear hiking (wool or wicking). Wear supportive clothing, a good sports bra & bring water. 

Kangoo Rental Sizes:

Small - Womens 4-6 or Mens 3-5
Medium - Womens 6-9 Mens 6-8
Large - Womens 10-12 Mens 9-11
XLarge - Womens 12+, Mens 12-15

Action Required After RSVP:
Please add your Kangoo size to the comments board so that I can arrange to have them onsite for the class.


Communications:
I'll arrive on site early and will use the meetup board to communicate. I'll send my contact info to those that RSVP. Please use text when contacting me if poss.


Misc but Important:
- Don't video tape anyone the without their consent, pics are fine

- Don't eat a full meal up to an hour before class.

- Open lockers are right by the front door so leave your valuables in car or at home.

- Bring cash/exact change (if possible) to expedite 

- Bring a snack with you for the ride home.

- Zumba class lets out prior to the Kangoo classes, there may not be much room to in the foyer to wait around for Zuma to end. I like to wait until the Zuma class exits the building before entering.

- You can not just show up at this event without an RSVP. Kangoos are brought to the location based on your RSVP & size + class size must be controlled due to type of activity. 

Prereqs:
Anyone with basic concepts of aerobics, step, boxing or zumba/dance and enjoys a high intensity cardio workout.

Future Kangoo Jump Events:
Kangoo jump weekend hikes will be posted to meetup under Southeastern Hiking Club (SHC) starting in May. 

Disclaimer:
During all events, everyone is responsible for themselves. Meetup hosts, organizers, assistant organizers, leaders, guides and sponsors are not responsible for the safety of participants. By joining the group, you acknowledge and agree to this statement.

results.description:
April's full moon is all about healing yourself emotionally, physically, and spiritually so that you are a full and empowered being ready to get down and do your soul work this summer.

The full moon is a time of positive opportunity if you use it correctly. It can increase your positive energy or conversely, it can wreak havoc on your emotions. Since the full moon pours down a tremendous amount of energy, you must be in a calm state of mind to receive a positive effect. Remember that whatever is going on in your body, mind and spirit will be amplified. If you are angry, you will feel angrier or if you are happy, you will feel happier. During the full moon, energies is very powerful so it’s important to direct it with positive intention.

During this FULL MOON Meditation for Healing we will gather in a sacred space where you ill be guided through a meditation to ground, balance and open you to receive the positive energies available to you during this powerful full moon! 

This group is for all levels!

Nicol will be leading this group.

Suggested Donation $10pp Cast at door or checks made to Saltonstall PTO! **  

**ALL funds from this group meditation will be donated to DI of the TIGER's trip to Global Finals in Tennessee coming up in May! **
results.name: **Full Moon Group Meditation to Benefit DI of the Tiger's to Global Finals!

results.description:
Each and every Friday, we're proud to open the doors of our music school in Central Square for a FREE seminar, demo or meet-up. Hell, we’ll even throw a classical music concert or two. What's in store this week? Let's find out:

Do you get confused when to mix the next song? Don't have enough time to mix the next song in?

This workshop will show you how and where to set loops and cue points to help make your transitions seamless from one song to the next. Setting cue points and loops is often an underutilized tool that many DJ's don't think to use. In this workshop I'll cover some of the basics on the when, where, and how to set and use these functions to improve your dj sets.

Chris Ward is the co-­founder and long time resident of Boston’s original and longest running dubstep night BASSIC Boston. He has over 10 years of experience organizing music events and getting behind a set of turntables. As a kid he grew up on a steady diet of metal/hardcore, hip­hop, and the his parents’ collection from the 50’s, 60’s, and 70’s. His love for music had him to making mixtapes on his parents cassette decks when he only in middle school. But, Chris’ interest in deejaying didn’t come about till high school after attending some local events where he heard deejays spinning jungle. His desire for knowledge mixed with a little bit of OCD led him to start collecting records and watch his favorite deejays to learn as much as he could whenever possible. His passion for music, like his record collection spans far and wide from jazz to experimental and everything in between. Chris has opened for numerous artists, and has played at countless venues throughout the New England area. As a performer whether cutting and blending hip­hop to mixing dubstep or jungle on 3 decks Chris is obsessed with finding the perfect mix.

Using Loops & Cue Points to Mix in Serato
Friday, April 22nd @ 7pm
Free
Mmmmaven
614 Massachusetts Avenue #203
Cambridge, MA 02139

results.description:
Join us for an evening of fun and connection as we play 3 communication games where we get the opportunity to say the truth and be real with each other (no touching and no one takes off any clothes). It's a great start to your evening!


Imagine meeting new people in an environment where everyone feels comfortable to be themselves. It’s a refreshing change from the typical networking or bar conversation—a place where everyone gets to say the truth and feel heard. Through other people putting quality attention on you, and asking you questions with genuine curiosity, and then listening—really listening—to your responses, you have the opportunity to examine yourself. It’s a friendly invitation to play and push your edges in a way that feels good, which allows you to stretch yourself and inspires self-discovery!

You can play at whatever level feels comfortable to you. You don't have to do anything you don't want to, or answer any questions you don't want to answer. The games are designed to create the sensations in your body that you might have during Orgasmic Meditation* without having to actually do the practice—just through talking. What comes up might surprise you.

Even in a room full of strangers, it's amazing how connected we can end up feeling when we are willing to be authentic. It's like a giant exhale when the rest of the world is asking you to hold it in. In just an hour, you may even forget that you are in Boston. 

*At the end of the evening we will tell you all about how you can learn the practice of Orgasmic Meditation, which class or private training you can take with our masterful teachers and coaches, and what we have to offer so you can have more connection, authenticity, and play in your life!

$10, payable at the door.

Please arrive on time—we lock the door promptly at 7:40!

Limited non-resident parking is available alongside our building on Dudley Street, or plentiful metered spaces on Mass Ave are only one block away (and free after 6pm). Or Print this parking pass to park in any resident permit space: www.turnonboston.com/parking/[masked]-22.pdf

We are a 10-minute walk from the Red Line at Davis Square or Alewife station.

Nicole Daedone (founder of Orgasmic Meditation) on the science of OM:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qg59pToG-Bk&ebc=ANyPxKq5gRnQf_jjWM_RZoCU4BnjyJ3-SMZpf8urZ5SRhyRtOo2yq3hh0SJoMjckytt2C0TE0DkhdufRilud2cfOT8_DxjM_2g

results.description:
Fridays, March – mid-November | 8:30 – 10:00 pm
Offering Format: Public Event
Recommended for grades Pre-K – 12 and adults
Museum of Science
Free

Did you know that the Museum offers our starry-eyed public a free evening full of astronomy-themed fun on weather-cooperative Fridays?

Between 8:30pm and 10pm each Friday, weather-permitting, visit the Gilliland Observatory on the roof of the Museum’s parking garage. On clear nights, you can view stars, planets, the Moon, and other astronomical phenomena. On cloudy nights, tour the inside of our Observatory, and participate in astronomy-related activities run by our knowledgeable staff.

This program does not run on nights when the weather is inclement. For more details, and to find out if Astronomy After Hours is running on a given Friday, call our hotline,[masked]-0267. We update each Friday by 5:30pm with the evening’s plans.

Astronomy After Hours runs seasonally, from the first Friday in March to the last Friday before Thanksgiving. Admission is free thanks to the generosity of the Lowell Institute (parking charges still apply).

Thanks to Don Doughty for letting us know about the museum.

Source: http://www.mos.org/public-events/astronomy-after-hours

results.description:
Here's another source of great info so I added these here and I'll add the rest in other posts...

January 3, 4 - Quadrantids Meteor Shower. The Quadrantids is an above average shower, with up to 40 meteors per hour at its peak. It is thought to be produced by dust grains left behind by an extinct comet known as 2003 EH1, which was discovered in 2003. The shower runs annually from January 1-5. It peaks this year on the night of the 3rd and morning of the 4th. The second quarter moon will block out all but the brightest meteors this year, but it could still be a good show if you are patient. Best viewing will be from a dark location after midnight. Meteors will radiate from the constellation Bootes, but can appear anywhere in the sky.

April 22, 23 - Lyrids Meteor Shower. The Lyrids is an average shower, usually producing about 20 meteors per hour at its peak. It is produced by dust particles left behind by comet C/1861 G1 Thatcher, which was discovered in 1861. The shower runs annually from April 16-25. It peaks this year on the night of the night of the 22nd and morning of the 23rd. These meteors can sometimes produce bright dust trails that last for several seconds. Unfortunately this year the glare from the full moon will block out all but the brightest meteors. If you are patient, you should still be able to catch a few good ones. Best viewing will be from a dark location after midnight. Meteors will radiate from the constellation Lyra, but can appear anywhere in the sky.

May 6, 7 - Eta Aquarids Meteor Shower. The Eta Aquarids is an above average shower, capable of producing up to 60 meteors per hour at its peak. Most of the activity is seen in the Southern Hemisphere. In the Northern Hemisphere, the rate can reach about 30 meteors per hour. It is produced by dust particles left behind by comet Halley, which has known and observed since ancient times. The shower runs annually from April 19 to May 28. It peaks this year on the night of May 6 and the morning of the May 7. The new moon will ensure dark skies this year for what could be an excellent show. Best viewing will be from a dark location after midnight. Meteors will radiate from the constellation Aquarius, but can appear anywhere in the sky.

July 28, 29 - Delta Aquarids Meteor Shower. The Delta Aquarids is an average shower that can produce up to 20 meteors per hour at its peak. It is produced by debris left behind by comets Marsden and Kracht. The shower runs annually from July 12 to August 23. It peaks this year on the night of July 28 and morning of July 29. The second quarter moon will block most of the fainter meteors this year but if you are patient you should still be able to catch quite a few good ones. Best viewing will be from a dark location after midnight. Meteors will radiate from the constellation Aquarius, but can appear anywhere in the sky.

August 12, 13 - Perseids Meteor Shower. The Perseids is one of the best meteor showers to observe, producing up to 60 meteors per hour at its peak. It is produced by comet Swift-Tuttle, which was discovered in 1862. The Perseids are famous for producing a large number of bright meteors. The shower runs annually from July 17 to August 24. It peaks this year on the night of August 12 and the morning of August 13. The waxing gibbous moon will set shortly after midnight, leaving fairly dark skies for should be an excellent early morning show. Best viewing will be from a dark location after midnight. Meteors will radiate from the constellation Perseus, but can appear anywhere in the sky.

October 7 - Draconids Meteor Shower. The Draconids is a minor meteor shower producing only about 10 meteors per hour. It is produced by dust grains left behind by comet 21P Giacobini-Zinner, which was first discovered in 1900. The Draconids is an unusual shower in that the best viewing is in the early evening instead of early morning like most other showers. The shower runs annually from October 6-10 and peaks this year on the the night of the 7th. The first quarter moon will block the fainter meteors in the early evening. It will set shortly after midnight leaving darker skies for observing any lingering stragglers. Best viewing will be in the early evening from a dark location far away from city lights. Meteors will radiate from the constellation Draco, but can appear anywhere in the sky.

October 21, 22 - Orionids Meteor Shower. The Orionids is an average shower producing up to 20 meteors per hour at its peak. It is produced by dust grains left behind by comet Halley, which has been known and observed since ancient times. The shower runs annually from October 2 to November 7. It peaks this year on the night of October 21 and the morning of October 22. The second quarter moon will block some of the fainter meteors this year, but the Orionids tend to be fairly bright so it could still be a good show. Best viewing will be from a dark location after midnight. Meteors will radiate from the constellation Orion, but can appear anywhere in the sky.

November 4, 5 - Taurids Meteor Shower. The Taurids is a long-running minor meteor shower producing only about 5-10 meteors per hour. It is unusual in that it consists of two separate streams. The first is produced by dust grains left behind by Asteroid 2004 TG10. The second stream is produced by debris left behind by Comet 2P Encke. The shower runs annually from September 7 to December 10. It peaks this year on the the night of November 4. The first quarter moon will set just after midnight leaving dark skies for viewing. Best viewing will be just after midnight from a dark location far away from city lights. Meteors will radiate from the constellation Taurus, but can appear anywhere in the sky.

November 17, 18 - Leonids Meteor Shower. The Leonids is an average shower, producing up to 15 meteors per hour at its peak. This shower is unique in that it has a cyclonic peak about every 33 years where hundreds of meteors per hour can be seen. That last of these occurred in 2001. The Leonids is produced by dust grains left behind by comet Tempel-Tuttle, which was discovered in 1865. The shower runs annually from November 6-30. It peaks this year on the night of the 17th and morning of the 18th. The waning gibbous moon will block many of the fainter meteors this year, but if you are patient you should be able to catch quite a few good ones. Best viewing will be from a dark location after midnight. Meteors will radiate from the constellation Leo, but can appear anywhere in the sky.

December 13, 14 - Geminids Meteor Shower. The Geminids is the king of the meteor showers. It is considered by many to be the best shower in the heavens, producing up to 120 multicolored meteors per hour at its peak. It is produced by debris left behind by an asteroid known as 3200 Phaethon, which was discovered in 1982. The shower runs annually from December 7-17. It peaks this year on the night of the 13th and morning of the 14th. The nearly full moon will block out many of the fainter meteors this year, but the Geminids are so bright and numerous that it could still be a good show. Best viewing will be from a dark location after midnight. Meteors will radiate from the constellation Gemini, but can appear anywhere in the sky.

Source(s):
http://www.seasky.org/astronomy/astronomy-calendar-2016.html
results.name: Next Meteor Shower

WHERE: Trip to Costa Rica

TYPE: Beach, Jungle or Volcano

WHAT: Trip to paradise for Surf, Stand Up Paddleboard, Yoga, Horsebackriding, Zipline, ATV Tour (Coffee/Jungle/Waterfall), Waterfall Hike
OR: Volcano Tours, Rainforest Excursions, Brewery Tours, Fishing

AIRPORT: LIBERIA, COSTA RICA (LIR) (arriving and departing between 11:30am and 3:30pm get you best shuttle rates) PRICES (APPX):


$499pp Hostel Camamar Bronze Package Bronze: accommodations, meals & airport transfer.


$899 Hostel Camamar Silver Package: accommodations, meals, airport transfer & surf lesson, sup lesson, snorkeling and horsebackriding (or substitute yoga).


$1000+ for Gold Packages at Camamar, Tortuga, Mariposa, Azul, Diria, etc. that include a car rental/tour guide, additional or different activities, and higher level accommodation in either a lodge, boutique hotel, hotel or resort.

I live down there most of the winter teaching surf, sup and bringing people around on tour guides. More than likely I would be your guide on any package over $1000. Other packages, you don't have any transportation to get around, but are still in an amazing place on a budget!

A common package would be a $1199 all inclusive package.

Camamar Hostel is DIRECTLY on the surf break in an ideal location if you can handle sharing a room and a bathroom with someone and no A/C, but with a ceiling fan. Low budget with location, location, location! More accommodations at:
http://supsonas.com/costarica/tripaccommodations.html

Fill out trip questionnaire and we will get you a quote.
http://supsonas.com/costarica/tripquestionnaire.html

Or message me or call me with any questions. [masked]

Pura vida!
Stacey Mac

Minuteman Trail -- 8:30 AM Prompt Start (the longer we wait the more joggers we will have to dodge)

We'll take the minuteman Trail from Alewife Station in Cambridge to Bedford and back. 

It's roughly a 20 miles bike ride on a fairly flat, paved path.  Speed will vary depending on rider's capability and how many walkers and joggers we'll have to dodge along the path.  Historically, this ride averages 13 mph pace.  Here is a link to the website of the minuteman trial (Link). 

Meeting Location: Alewife T Stop, WEST side Pedal and Park Cage (there are 3 so pay close attention).  The West cage is location at the corner of Cambridge Park Pl and Alewife Station Access Road closes to the trailhead.

The Pedal & Park Cage is located partially under the parking garage as shown here:


Bike Route

results.description:
We will run down Comm Ave in the carriage lane to the Chestnut Hill/BC reservoir, with the option to run around the reservoir before turning around. This is an out and back course so the distance is flexible - you can run however many miles you want!  There are some hills - we will run 3 of the 4 Newton Hills along the Boston Marathon course (if you go at least 8 miles - 4 out and 4 back).

Meet outside at the tables next to Bruegger's and the ATM.  We will leave right at 8:30 AM (especially when it is cold out!).

The pace will vary depending on who shows up.  If there is a wide range of paces, we frequently end up splitting into smaller groups based on pace.  Even if your pace doesn't "match up" with anyone else, meeting up with the group and starting the run with everyone is a great way to get yourself out of bed on those early Saturday mornings!
results.name: Comm Ave long run  8-15+ miles

results.description:
Join Fitbit local as they launch their first community-based fitness class in Boston on Saturday, April 23rd. Fitbit Local Ambassadors Cara Gilman and Chad Flahive will lead an energizing, all-levels workout that combines a bodyweight bootcamp and yoga flow. There will be a DJ, health snacks and raffle giveaways. Check out what your local Fitbit team is doing in the community!

Free Registration here: 

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/fitbit-local-boston-tickets-24236782870?aff=es2
results.name: Fitbit Local Boston

group.name: Balanced In Boston: healthy living meetup group

results.description: Traditional ballet barre toning with an easy to learn dance segment. The dance is more of a classic burlesque style..Give me once a week and you will see results within a month.
results.name: CaBARREt FIT

results.description:
Note:  This Meetup will always say "full" with only the organizer attending. In order to reserve your spot, you must sign up at www.llbean.com/dedham

Join us for a 4 mile hike around Borderlands State Park.  We'll explore around the much-nicer-than-it-sounds Leach Pond before heading up hill to the original quarry and exploring the trails.

NOTE:  This is a DCR facility, and there's parking fee of $5 (payable at the parking lot machine at the entrance gate - bring dollar bills or coins)

ACTIVITY LEVEL:  Easy to Moderate

Age:  8+

WHAT TO BRING:  Hiking appropriate footwear, weather appropriate clothing, insect repellent, sunglasses, water for 3 hours, snacks.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the benches in front of the welcome center.
results.name: Hike Borderlands State Park

results.description:
Their major issue is that they have tons of donations, and not even close enough amount of volunteers, to sort useable vs. recycle goods.  

http://thewishproject.org/ 

The Wish Project is a non-profit dedicated to providing free furniture, home goods, baby goods, and clothing to people in need in the Merrimack Valley, primarily through reuse and recycling. They serve thousands of people each year, and rely on the help of many volunteers. Let's be some of those volunteers! We'll take on whatever task they need on this day, but generally it involves sorting and organizing donations so they can be given out to clients. Children ages 8+ are welcome to join the effort. It's a great opportunity to teach your kids compassion in a very hands-on way. 

IMPORTANT:

If you are bringing children, please make a note in the comments section so I can give the Wish Project an accurate count of adults and kids who will be attending.

http://thewishproject.org/

 *PLEASE NOTE:  When you RSVP 'yes' it becomes a commitment. I am in contact with the volunteer coordinator, Patty, whom is now a member, giving her a head count. She then creates a list of things that need to be done -relying upon the number of volunteers. If your plans change, please be considerate -take a moment to update your RSVP to 'no.' It's very simple- and greatly appreciated! Thanks :)
results.how_to_find_us: The WORD is out, n' spreading!
results.name: Giving Back aka Volunteering @ The Wish Project - Lowell

results.description:
Golf season is not too far away. 

Please let me know if you are interested in signing up for the Saturday a.m. mixed league at Middleton Golf Course. 

The league plays from 4/16 through 8/27 and there are contests and prizes each week.


This is a par 3 course so you can practice your short game.  The fee to join is $40 and it covers your handicap fee.  You can play 9 or 18 but have to decide which option when you sign up each week.

This league is flexible!

Tee times are from 7:30 to 10:30 and you are NOT required to play every week.  I will make the tee time the week of play and it is usually around 9-10 am until it gets hot and then 8-9 am.

The website is www.middletongolf.com

There are leagues every day if Saturday does not fit your schedule.
results.how_to_find_us: at the course
results.name: Middleton Saturday morning golf league

results.description:
A bunch of you already know about this but just a reminder for everyone... free SGX workout in Boston on 4/23!! Unfortunately I can't make it but hope that most of you go! Feel free to leave some comments and plan to meet up with each other! Take pictures :)

More info / sign up at:
https://www.facebook.com/events/1714556642113873/

AROO!
results.name: FREE Spartan SGX Workout!

results.description:
Come paddle at one of our practice sessions with Living Root, your 2015 Boston Dragon Boat Festival Grand Champions! We're a social and friendly co-ed team who enjoy the sport of dragon boat paddling.

Are you new to paddling? No problem! We'll show you everything you need to know to paddle on a dragon boat. This is a great way to meet people, get in shape, and do something fun in the sun.

We paddle rain or shine, so dress for the weather. Wear comfortable workout clothing and footwear that you don't mind getting wet. Bring a bottle of water, and we'll provide all the paddling equipment you'll need and a place to lock up your belongings. We often head out for a quick bite to eat after practice. So come join us! Send questions to: Dave Parker at [masked].

Additional Location and Parking information can be found here

Check out our website or find us on Facebook!
results.how_to_find_us: There's a pavilion near the docks, behind an MGH building (it used to be Spaulding Rehab Hospital).  Parking is around at the Galleria Mall, Science Museum or North Point Park street parking.
results.name: Living Root Dragon Boat Practice Session

results.description:
Note:  Pose will be the same as the Friday 4-hour sessions, so if you want to get a REALLY long pose, sign up for both.  

Jeremy Durling will host- Jeremy's paintings are available through the Sloane Merrill Gallery on Charles Street in Boston.  

Members (those paying the $25 monthly membership fee) may reserve a spot for $55, non-members for $70.    Three hours each Saturday morning, 9:30-12:30.  You can come individual days by paying $15 (members) or $25 (non-members) for a single drop-in, but please consider paying for the full amount and committing to come!  It will help us to keep these long sessions going, and even if you pay for the whole session and don't come to all of them (often happens), you're getting a pretty square deal.  If you would like to pay online please do so at

http://damonlehrer.com/damonlehrer.com/payment.html


PLEASE TRY TO BE ON TIME-  folks who come later than 10:00 am will be admitted ONLY at the convenience of the host (who is busy painting). PLEASE NOTE THE PRICES BELOW- They are deliberately a bit higher than for drawing sessions as we keep the studio less crowded for painting, and it's more work to put together a four week pose.  

----- IF THE CAPACITY REACHES 12, whether or not that number shows up on the RSVP list, we may have to close the session to further drop-ins to preserve breathing space for those who reserved ahead. ------

 Please consider that for $55 or $65 (non-member) you can reserve ahead for the whole month, which helps us stay open for business.  If you want to drop in, you can RSVP and pay online- simply change the amount of the payment at the payment stage to reflect the drop-in rate above.
results.how_to_find_us: Corner of Central Street and Vernon Street, big brick building.  Park on Vernon street in front of building or in lot behind building.
results.name: Saturday morning painting four week pose

results.description:
Greetings everyone,

Come on out Saturday mornings at 9:30 for my Core Vinyasa yoga class. 


All levels are welcome from pure beginners to more advanced yoga practitioners.  Options will be given for everyone.  This class will have some core work at the beginning, some flow, some alignment, and some relaxation at the end.  Please let me know if you have any questions or if you have specific needs or injuries, you would like feedback on.


New member special $25 for two weeks of unlimited yoga.

Drop in = $16

10 class cards available for $130.


Thanks everyone!

Jason
results.how_to_find_us: Follow down the driveway....
results.name: Core Vinyasa Yoga - New students welcome! New member special!

group.name: Dorchester Yoga Lovers, Likers, and Newbies!

venue.address_1: 50 Milk Street, 5th floor Meridian Conference Room
venue.name: CIC Boston

results.description:
Are you curious about programming or thinking about pursuing a career in software engineering? 

Then RSVP on this meet-up page for this 2-hour Intro to Coding class happening in the Boston area at CIC Boston. Learn the basics of programming, do hands-on exercises, and meet new people. All for free!

The class is being taught by MakerSquare, which runs some of the top coding schools in the country.

Class officially starts at 9:30am, but please arrive at CIC Boston by 9:15am to mingle with your fellow classmates and settle in. We will end at 12noon, with the last 30 minutes being an optional Q&A session.

What will I learn during the class?

This beginner ­level class will contain several instructor-guided exercises. The class will cover the following topics:

   1. Overview of programming 

   2. Intro to data & data structures

   3. Basics of functions

We ask that you read the Prerequisites section before the start of class and bring your own laptop (Windows, Mac or Linux) with Google Chrome installed.

What is MakerSquare Boston?

MakerSquare is a three-month full-time school for software engineering. By teaching computer science fundamentals and modern web languages like JavaScript, we prepare students to join top flight engineering teams.

We have campuses all over the country, and are excited to be opening a campus in Boston. The free Intro to Coding class is to introduce more people to the wonderful world of programming and to get the community excited about the launch of our full-time class in Boston in July 2016!

Questions? Email us at [masked].
results.name: Free Intro to Coding Class (Sat April 23, 9:30am-12noon)

results.description:
Let's meet and walk for at least an hour. Our route Saturday will be thru town, up Prospect Street, (a rather large hill) over to Rowley Bridge Road, left at Cross Street, (another large hill), Salem Road, River Road, Prospect St, down the hill  and back downtown.   Our walks are brisk.  You will get your heart rate up.  Most walking will be on the street, some will be on sidewalks.  Following our walk, we frequently get a coffee/tea at one of the shops in town.

Hope you can make it!  It's fun!

<a href="http://www.meetup.com/North-Shore-Womens-Group/events/229051918/#"></a>
results.name: Walk  in Topsfield...

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/sort-food-at-the-greater-boston-food-bank-tickets-21414594629


Volunteers will help sort donated food that is distributed to the Greater Boston Community. The food could be can goods/non perishable or perishable items.

Please wear comfortable shoes since volunteers will be standing walking in the volunteers shift.   We need to provide a list to the Food Bank so please provide your last name.

results.name: Sort Food at the Food Bank (April)

results.description:
Let's meet for a Saturday Morning Beginner-Friendly Bike Ride at Town Hall in Braintree!  We will be meeting and biking around the main roads and neighborhoods.  Let's meetup and get to know each other while biking around the neighborhoods of Braintree!

 
We will bike 5-8 miles in about 45 minutes. We will stop along the way every couple of miles or so. I do keep track of our mileage, time, etc. via an app on my phone.  (If you have an app to track as well please do so.)  Please bring your own bike.

Please be advised we are not professional bikers and this is a leisurely let's-get-back-into-biking ride.  I personally am training for a 25 mile bike ride in June and the early spring rides are more leisurely and shorter than the bike rides in May and June.  I will be happy to host and post some of my other training rides, especially if anyone is interested in participating in the 15 or 25 mile bike rides in June.  If I am able to do so I will bring a pump for your tires. It is my recommendation that you go for a 4-5 mile or 1/2 hr bike ride prior to attending this event.  If you belong to a gym I recommend biking for time &/or mileage a couple of times over the winter before biking outside.  Additionally, I will most likely have a friend join us for the bike ride regardless of whether or not guests are welcome.

 
Please Note: 

1. If you RSVP Yes please honor your commitment and attend.  If you are unable to attend for any reason please change your RSVP.  If it's too late to do so please post a note on the event wall or send one of the event hosts a message through meetup.  It's the nice thing to do.

2. Pace: As noted above, we will be biking 5-8 miles in the course of 45-60 minutes so we will bike an average speed of 6-10mph today.

3. Please wear a helmet and review the rules of road.  Event Host/Organizer(s) are not responsible for any injuries or liabilities caused by participants.

4. This is weather-dependent. If the ground is too wet we will not bike.  I will post an update in the Conversations a few days prior to the event with a status update. 

5. As an aside, this Spring (March/April/May/maybe early June) my intent is to host Beginner-Friendly Bike Ride as follows: 1-2 in March, 2 April, and 1 in May (3-6 total).  More advanced Bike Rides for Advanced Beginner and Intermediate will be done in April, May, and June.  May and June Bike Rides will be focused on training for the Habitat Bike Ride in June.  After the Habitat Bike Ride and various activities and events in June I hope to resume hosting 1 monthly bike ride starting in July, mostly AB and Intermediate but will add a BF Bike Ride in late summer/early Fall.  *We are  always looking to add people to co/host BF and AB (or even Intermediate) Bike Rides, so please let me know so we can get you some co/hosting experience this Spring.*

***If you want to get back into biking this year then these Beginner-Friendly Bike Rides are the way to go!!  They will be limited in 2016 unless someone else wants to co-host as most of my bike rides will be for Advanced Beginners and Intermediates this year.  So, don't miss out on this event!!!***

Optional: We can grab some yogurt/ice cream in South Braintree Square at The Yogurt Bar to continue socializing.

 ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Biking Levels (Rough Guide):

~Beginner-Friendly: Approximately 5-8 miles of relatively flat terrain biking an average speed of 5-10mph in 45 minutes time.  All levels welcome.

~Advanced Beginner: Either approximately 8-15 miles of mostly flat terrains with some small hills OR approximately 4-6 miles of mostly hills.  (Great for training and getting the heart rate up.)  The flatter longer terrain will have average speeds of 6-12mph biking in about 45 minutes to an hour.  The hillier shorter terrain will have varying average speeds probably closer to 3-4mph uphill and 15+mph (yikes!) downhill averaging 4-12mph.  Both will take about 45 minutes to 1 hr and 15 minutes.  All levels upward welcome.  (Beginner-Friendly bikers may be able to join us on some of these rides. Please check w/ the Event Host(s)/Organizer(s) before signing up to join this type of event.)

~Intermediate: Ride length of 12-25 miles with varying degrees of flat and hilly terrains.  We'll be biking about 8-15mph in about 1-1.5hours.

~Advanced: You can bike 20+ miles in about 1& 1/2-2 hours at an average speed of 12-20mph.

~Expert: You can do it all!!  This is a rare group of talented individuals.

***As always, safety first!  Please wear a helmet and review the rules of road.  Event Host/Organizer(s) are not responsible for any injuries or liabilities caused by participants. Bike Rides are weather-dependent. If the ground is too wet we will not bike.  I will post an update in the Conversations a few days prior to the event with a status update.***

>>>This can also be found pinned on the Discussions tab.  Here is the direct link. http://www.meetup.com/SocialFun/messages/boards/thread/48762263
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

South Shore Beginner-Friendly Sunday Afternoon Bike Ride in April

Saturday, April 23rd @ 9:30-11am
Braintree Town Hall

1 JFK Memorial Drive (parallel and adjacent to Washington Street)

No Phone #.
Meeting Location: Meet by the portico on the side of Town Hall near the mailboxes.  Look for our bikes!

Event Organizer/Host(s): Angela & TBD (A co-host would be most welcome and appreciated, especially if you want to host bike rides this season.)

Min/Max: At least 4 Yes RSVPs 48 hours prior to the event (excluding Host and any of Host's Guests). Attendance is currently limited to 18 total people.   (The WL is set to Automatic, meaning as a spot opens up the next person on the WL will automatically be moved to the Yes list.  Please be sure to change your RSVP if you are no longer able to attend.)

Guests: 1 adult per member is welcome.

Late Arrivals: We will wait our traditional 5-10 minutes.  Please note we probably won't circle back to the meeting location till the end of the ride.

Cost/Fees: There are currently no costs or fees associated with this event.  If you have attended at least 3 SSHBSC events and want to make a voluntary donation to SSHBSC I will be happy to collect and mail it to Roger.

RSVP Deadline: Please finalize your RSVP by 6pm on Friday, April 22nd.  Any changes made after this time may not be seen by an Event Organizer prior to the event and are subject to our No-Show policy.  The Event Organizer(s)/Host(s) reserves the right to cancel this event if we have less than 6 Yes RSVPs at the RSVP Deadline.  (You can RSVP on the site up until the start of the event today.)  You can change your RSVP until 8am on the day of the event without being considered a No-Show.

Inclement Weather: TBD.  Any precipitation (especially this early in the season) will cancel.

Rain Date: None at this time, however, we are working on an evening bike ride sometime in April.  We will be hosting more Beginner-Friendly Bike Rides throughout the season.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Directions to Braintree Town Hall @ 1 JFK Memorial Drive on Washington Street:

Overview: Located near South Braintree Square, directly across from the Thayer Public Library and next to Thayer Academy, Town Hall is a short walk from the Braintree T and a short drive from Route 3.

From Routes 24/95/128/93:

Head towards Route 3 South/Braintree/Cape Cod.

From Route 3: Take Exit 17/Union Street/Braintree (it will be your 2nd exit on Route 3 South), take the 1st right off the exit ramp (from Route 3 southbound/3rd right from Route 3 northbound) keeping Motel 6 on your left.  Get in one of the middle lanes and go straight thru the 1st set of lights going under the overpass and keeping the T on your left.  Take a left at the light at the top of the hill and get in the right lane.  Take a right at the next light and an immediate left into the Town Hall parking lot.

From the Braintree T on Foot (Walking):

Exit the T heading towards Union Street and South Braintree Square.  Leave the front door, take a left and head towards the street (it's a one way so you may see a bus or taxi heading your way), then go down the steps and take a left heading under the underpass up the hill.  At the top of the hill at the light round the corner to your left heading towards The Fire Station.  At the next light if you walk diagonally across the street you will be at Town Hall.  Basically, cross the street in front of the fire station and then use the signal to cross Washington Street, or use the signal to cross Washington Street and then cross Central Street.  You will be at the Town Hall Mall once you have crossed the street(s).

Parking: Free and ample parking at Town Hall, generally.  If the Town Hall parking lot is full you can drive across Central Street and park in the Thayer Academy parking lot along Central Street (away from the school buildings).

Note: All of Angela's events are child-free and pet-free for adults 21+ only unless otherwise noted.  Thank you for being respectful of this request.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet in the parking lot next to Town Hall nearest the mailboxes.  Look for my bike and my Black Toyota RAV4.
results.name: South Shore Beginner-Friendly Saturday Morning Bike Ride in April

group.name: South Shore Hike, Bike & Social Club

results.description:
It's never a bad time to up your game a notch or two and if you have managed to get off auto but are wondering what;s next - then here is the one day class just for you.

Spend  a day with Ian in a small group where individual attention is assured and learn how to:

• Manage your camera's metering 

• Understand how to get creative with exposure

• Get creative with shutter speed

• Learn how to add more depth to your shots

• Learn how to employ line and shape into your composition

• Learn  to control depth of field

• Learn the techniques for eliminating unwanted elements from your shot

• And more.

This class is suitable for anyone who had learned their camera controls and is comfortable adjusting aperture, ISO and shutter speed.  Instruction will be provided on metering modes.  All you need is a digital SLR camera (or mirror less) and a willingness to try out some challenging exercises.

We will meet at Hunt's Camera Store in Hanover at 10am and head out from there to an interesting local area to spend a day in a completely hands-on session with expert guidance and instruction from Ian.  The day will end around 4pm.

We will take a break for lunch in the middle of the session,
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at Hunt's Camera Store on rt53 in Hanover (next to Target)
results.name: Take it up a notch (or two)

results.description:
...Seeking healing, wholeness, wisdom, beauty and joy in the nearby natural world through intention, awareness and creative engagement...

What is your usual intention when you head into nature?  What works for you?  What are some other possibilities?

How can you more deeply engage and FEEL connected with the natural world?  How might you more fully receive what arrives when you show up?

What could you offer back as a creative response?  With your voice, movement, rhythm, words, story-making, music-making, art-making, activism, ceremony ... or something else?


How might you receive healing or guidance from the natural world?

How might you build a relationship with a particular place, plant, animal or rock?

 Our activities together will draw on insights and practices from ancient and contemporary sources including:  energy medicine, qigong, neuro-linguistic programming, InterPlay, shamanism, plant spirit medicine and folk traditions. 

We'll begin indoors, later heading out together, most likely carpooling to the Acton Arboretum (depending on weather.)


Stay tuned for further details.
results.name: Suburban Nature Questing

group.name: The Energy Medicine Study Group in Littleton

venue.name: First Church of Roxbury - Outdoors

results.description:
Volunteer for $2 Bag of Vegetables at First Parish Roxbury

Do you want OTHER people to eat fresh produce?  Then help us - each Wednesday late afternoon - bag vegetables (and some fruit) for the neighbors in Roxbury (Roxbury Crossing and Fort Hill).  Usually there are also freshly-baked loaves of bread, also (baked that morning - Jessica's Bakery).

It's an assembly line, then take home a bag (or two) of produce for yourself. 

Bring your business cards, smartphone, or notepad, and prepare to exchange contact info with other volunteers you like.  Volunteers come from several sources (not merely from this meetup or others: Craigslist, Pharmacy School, School of Public Health, etc.) 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill 

First Church of Roxbury - Outdoors in good weather 
10 Putnam Street, John Eliot Square, Highland Park, Roxbury, Boston, MA

Each Saturday, from 10:00 am - 2:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)

We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Saturday mid-day $2/bag of produce in Roxbury.

When you volunteer, 
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"! 
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Roxbury neighbors so they can eat like me - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag. 

Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of density (potatoes on bottom - tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2).

We arrive around 10 am and work until 2 pm.

In FRONT of the 

First Church of Roxbury - Outdoors in good weather 
10 Putnam Street, John Eliot Square, Highland Park, Roxbury, Boston, MA

Each Saturday, from 10:00 am - 2:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)

the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop - is only a few blocks away; we are behind the Mosque, which has a $2 bag distribution from 1-3 pm that same afternoon.

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food. 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 

First Church of Roxbury - Outdoors in good weather 
10 Putnam Street, John Eliot Square, Highland Park, Roxbury, Boston, MA

Each Saturday, from 10:00 am - 2:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)


THERE IS PARKING - BUT IT'S BEST FOR THOSE WHO LIVE IN BOSTON AND TRAVEL IN ON THE MBTA

THERE IS PARKING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

Every Wednesday, from 10:00 am - 2:00 pm 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Bring friends!  Forward the invitation to others! 

Please e-mail organizer with your e-mail address and cellphone (in case we need to converse about this more, or contact you before the event). 

Invite FRIENDS through the Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter 'share' 
buttons 

Looking for an ARTIST to help VISUALLY REPRESENT this vegetable outreach effort. 

TALK with us FIRST !!

Looking for Gifted Marketers to 
(i) conceptualize the WHY of low cost vegetable distribution! and 
(ii) the desirability of TAKING the low cost vegetables !!

LOGISTICAL CHALLENGE IS TO GET LOW COST VEGETABLES to the REFRIGERATORS of LOCAL RESIDENTS !!! 

Looking for an ARTIST to help VISUALLY REPRESENT this vegetable outreach effort.  

TALK with us FIRST !! 

Looking for Gifted Marketers to 
(i) conceptualize the WHY of low cost vegetable distribution! and 
(ii) the desirability of TAKING the low cost vegetables !!

LOGISTICAL CHALLENGE IS TO GET LOW COST VEGETABLES to the REFRIGERATORS of LOCAL RESIDENTS !!!

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Vegan Cooking classes or Vegan Cooking Ideas 

Vegan Cooking Classes or 
                 Learning How to Prepare Vegan Food 
                    (using the $2 bag of produce as a low-cost start) 

* What Can You Do With Your $2 Bag? 
* Portion Control 
* Bake...Don't Fry! 
* Roasted Veggie Stackers 
* No-Guilt Banana Ice Cream 
* Avocados!!! 
* Salad with Chipotle Hummus 
* Simple Cilantro Chutney 
* More $2 bags of Produce! 
* Drink your greens!


Question: 
This sounds like a great deal, but is it meant for those in need, as is the case with food banks? 

Answer: 
No qualifications - no limits 
We have way more - far more - lots more - much more than AMPLE food for any intended audiences, and the operation is bettered if MORE people take the food than if FEWER take the food. 

Therefore, there is NO QUALIFICATION (no test of need) and no limit to how much you can cart off (just pay $2/bag and $1/loaf of bread).  That's why I post it on a meetup like this. 
Make us busy - very busy.
results.name: Volunteer for $2 Bag of Vegetables at First Parish Roxbury

results.description:
Free. Fun. Starts here!

Welcome to the Dedham Couch to 5K sponsored by St. Luke's Lutheran Church. We love people the Dedham area and want to help them in any way we can. 

We have 2 groups: 

Our Walking Group will exercise and encourage one another towards walking a 5K. 

Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K.

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace. 

• FREE 9-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners 

• Monday through Thursdays 6:30pm-7:15pm; Saturday 10:00 am-10:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week 

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Pack the Pantry 5K on June 11
results.name: Dedham Couch to 5K—Spring 2016

results.description:
At popular request, here's a easy starter hike that's close to Boston: we'll ascend Wright Tower on Pine Hill in Middlesex Fells reservation for a gorgeous view of city skyline. At only 150' elevation gain, it's just a short ascent but it feels like more than a nature walk. From there group vote on how long to go -and whether to meander, vs. continue upward to Bear Hill at the north end of the park, for a fuller hiking experience. Rain date Sun 4/23, same 10 am start time. Please bring water and wear trail-friendly shoes. While most trails in our favorite NH locations remain too icy for beginners/require traction, let's get our legs warmed up. Will post any weather rescheduling by Fri 4/22 evening at 9 pm.

Park at the Bellevue Pond parking area, off Roosevelt Circle, details:
http://www.friendsofthefells.org/directions/

See Boston Globe description of early part/tower:
http://www321.pair.com/oaries/localattitude/fellsky.htm

More detail and pics:
http://www.franklinsites.com/hikephotos/Massachusetts/pinehill-2014-1123.php

Trail details: http://www.friendsofthefells.org/trails/

Trail map: http://www.friendsofthefells.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/04/Fells_Reservation_Map.pdf
results.name: Middlesex Fells - easy starter hike to tower & more!

results.description:
Master Herbalist Nathan Searles of Forgotten Traditions will share his knowledge of mycology by shedding light on the basics of medicinal mushrooms. Class attendees will learn what qualifies as a mushroom, their ecological connections, some of New Hampshire’s native species, and traditional uses for these organisms. Space is limited so please sign up by calling (603)[masked] or emailing [masked]

There are about 15 spots remaining, carpool if you can. We can go to the NH Mushroom Company in Tamworth 153 Gardner Hill Rd. afterwards. I was told they give tours, it would interesting to see how they grow mushrooms. Dion  http://www.nhmushrooms.com/
results.name: Free Medicinal Mushroom Class by Nathan Searles

results.description:
Every Saturday morning at 10:00 AM we gather for a fun, calming group run at the Chestnut Hill Reservoir. Both walkers and runners are welcome. Our main goal is to socialize and support one another!

The Boston Bulldogs is a co-ed non-profit running club founded to support those battling addiction and in recovery, those who have been affected by addiction and their supporters.

We welcome and encourage runners of all levels – dreamers, beginners, as well as those with running experience, past or present. Our volunteer runners will be there to coach you at your current level, and help you meet your goals. We might even be able to help with running gear if needed. 

We meet twice weekly at the Chestnut Hill Reservoir (Cleveland Circle/Reservoir Green Line C or D train) -- on Saturday mornings at 10:00 AM and Thursday evenings at 6:30 PM. We first gather in front of the Cleveland Circle Starbucks, before heading over to the reservoir. See you there!

If you are interested in becoming a member or a volunteer, in making a contribution to the Club, in sponsoring a runner in recovery, or in learning more about the Boston Bulldog educational wellness/running program, contact us at:

• Website - BostonBulldogsRunning.com

• Email - [masked] 

• Phone -[masked]
results.how_to_find_us: We will start gathering outside the Starbucks at Cleveland Circle around 9:45am... see you then!

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!
results.how_to_find_us: Come around to the right side of the school (left side of the church), enter under the green awning, then up two flights to the gym!
results.name: (Cambridge) - Intermediate Swordplay, Dagger and Grappling

group.name: Boston Armizare -- Historical Swordplay and More!

results.description: This is a heads-up for the local sailing community and less of a standard Meetup. BHSC is having a three day open house from 10AM to 3PM on Saturday April 23, Sunday April 24 and Saturday April 30. While these are not sailing events, representative boats from each of the 26’-41’ size classes in the Club’s large cruising and racing fleet will be tied up dockside at Rowes Wharf. Tour the boats inside and out and learn what the Club has to offer straight from the source. Qualified members of this club also have access to cruising boats moored in Marblehead, Provincetown and Westport/Buzzard’s Bay.
results.name: Open House, Boston Harbor Sailing Club

results.description:
The Arnold Arboretum of Harvard University is an arboretum located in the Jamaica Plain and Roslindale sections of Boston, Massachusetts. It was designed by Frederick Law Olmsted and is the second largest "link" in the Emerald Necklace.

For more information

www.arboretum.harvard.edu

Right now the website says the Magnolias are beginning to bloom. Let's explore this beautiful area while getting fresh air and exercise.

For those who wish, we can have lunch afterwards.
results.name: Let's walk the Arnold Arboretum

results.description:
PLEASE NOTE THE CHANGE IN LOCATION

Please make sure to RSVP at this meetup event and checkin when you come in for the run. 

Group run logistics: Please come prepared for a short run (or run/walk). Leave your bags, etc. at home or in your car so that you can run easily. Please make sure to arrive 10 minutes early to look for parking, find the location, etc.  
Coach will brief you at the beginning of the run about the distance (~3 or 4 miles) and direct you through stretching exercises. It is absolutely OK to run/walk in the beginning. Many of us are first-time runners. So please don’t be shy :-). 

Parking: Please arrive 10+ minutes early to find parking near Davis Square. You can find free parking spots on the Holland Street if you drive a few blocks from Au Bon Pain towards Hodgkins Park. You can also find metered parking spots near Au Bon Pain. Remember to feed the meter to avoid getting ticket.

Program details:  TeamAIDAsha is a beginner-friendly marathon/half-marathon training and fund-raising program. We train runners for their full or half marathon races and runners raise donations for AID and Asha. Both beginner and experienced runners are welcome. Anyone is welcome to RSVP and join us for the group runs up to four time with no obligations. We request formal registrations after attending four group runs.

If you missed the information session you can get an overview of this training and fund-raising program from here.

Follow us on Facebook for news about running, AID and Asha

Looking for more runners: We are always looking for more runners. If any of your friends, family members or colleagues to give us a try and join this meetup group.


Waiver: Lawyers make us do this :-).  By running with TeamAIDAsha program you are agreeing to our official waiver at: http://www.teamaidasha.org/waiver.html
results.how_to_find_us: Look for a group of runners and volunteers
results.name: Beginner-friendly marathon/half-marathon training run

results.description:
This will be an approximately 6-8 mile loop hike on two beautiful adjacent Trustee's properties in bucolic Petersham. Although there are uphill sections, the hiking is on generally flat terrain but the foot paths are rocky and overgrown in some places and the old cart roads have sections of broken ground.

North Common Meadow is a rolling pasture land rich with wildflowers that descends into the Brooks Woodland Preserve's canopy of red oaks, hemlocks, and white pines.  These rolling lands were once home to Nipmuc Indians before being cleared for open pasture.  North Main Street, which overlooks North Common Meadow, is notable in Massachusetts history for being the site of an attack by  the Massachusetts militia upon a rebel encampment during Shays Rebellion in 1787.

What You Need To Know:

You need a recognizable facial photo as your profile picture in order to participate in this and all Trekkers events.

 Estimated Distance: 6-8miles (subject to change) 

Terrain Difficulty: Easy/Moderate This hike should be  suitable for  beginning hikers who keep fit doing other things. This rating typically describes hikes that are not flat but whose elevation gain is less than 500 feet per mile. For an easy/moderate hike, you should definitely be prepared for some uphill walking. As with all our hikes, expect rocky terrain, broken ground, big tree roots and wet leaves underfoot. Expect mud - embrace it! 

Remember that the Difficulty Rating is for the terrain; not the hike itself. When determining if a hike is right for you, remember to factor in: terrain, distance, estimated pace, duration, weather prediction, driving time and your fitness level as well as your mood and frustration threshold.

Elevation Gain: minimal over rolling terrain

Hike Time: Estimated 4 hours. However, this is an estimate. Actual times vary greatly according to weather, trail conditions and the pace of the  group. Don't sign up if you've scheduled something later in the day. The Organizer is not responsible for getting you back in time.

Anticipated Pace: 2-2.5 mph or the pace of the slowest hiker

Hike Type:  Loop (actually a series of interconnected loops)

There is no way of knowing trail conditions ahead of time. Use your own judgement.

Anyone with recurrent "No Shows" , or who routinely drops out or about whom we have received complaints from fellow Trekkers will not be accepted. If you haven't hiked with us before, add yourself to the list if you can adhere to these basic prerequisites.

Please don't RSVP "Yes" unless you really intend to come. We are committed to being there for you. If you are not equally committed to being there then please don't sign up.

Please do not show up for an event unexpected or unprepared. Bring water (2 liters), hiking boots (not sneakers or trail runners) and lunch/snacks. Protect yourself against deer ticks and dress in layers.

Please do not talk your cell phone (except for emergencies), listen to the radio or play music during the hike.

This event is a hike; not a guided nature walk or history talk. 

We don't leave the marked trails in pursuit of animals or their tracks. 

We hike in light rain or light snow, but any  extreme weather that renders hiking and/or driving conditions hazardous cancels. 

This is a group event and participants are expected to follow the lead, stay together, stop at junctions or summits, and support all participants should circumstances require teamwork. We start together and finish together. If you decide to leave the group at any time, you are on your own.

NO DOS and NO GUESTS.  Have your guest join the group so they can agree to the liability waiver and attend an event.

Please remember that your Event Organizers  are volunteers, the event is free and we are all adults. The people who have the best times on these hikes are those who stay loose and roll with things as they happen. If you are expecting Daniel Boone as your leader, you’re barking up the wrong tree. If you need everything to run perfectly, this hike is not for you.

Short Version: This not an event for high-maintenance individuals.

By signing up and/or attending this hike you agree to the Liability Waiver Below:  

Remember: Your Event Organizers  are volunteers. You are solely responsible for your own safety and enjoyment. As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you know and will follow the Hiker Responsibility Code described at http://www.hikesafe.com/

 You assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; the organizer(s) of this activity is a volunteer; and you for yourself, your heirs, executors, and administrators release, hold harmless, and indemnify organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reason.

If you are offering or need a ride, post that on the message board. However, when responding please do so privately by clicking on the person's profile pick and clicking the "message" link.

Please keep your carpooling arrangements private and  off the Message Board. For your safety don't post your phone number on the site.

For more info and a trail maps go to:

http://www.thetrustees.org/places-to-visit/central-ma/brooks-woodland-preserve.html

http://www.thetrustees.org/places-to-visit/central-ma/north-common-meadow.html

For driving directions go to::


http://www.thetrustees.org/places-to-visit/central-ma/north-common-meadow.html

If you park on East Street, walk up the hill and take a right @  the Petersham Store (intersection of East and North Main Street) to meet up @ in front of the Brooks Law office.

Wanna try us out? Come join us at our water training sessions! No prior experience necessary.


• First two practices are $10 (The $10 can go towards the full membership of $110 for the rest of the season). Pay via Paypal ("Boston 1 - Join us") or venmo (@boston1dboat).</a>

• Also you will not be allowed on the boats if you do not sign the waiver: <a href="https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1Ll2NR3MZbV3O7ZrmPdZsCbKRaC_G8KKa7lwBUlC59Pk/viewform?c=0&w=1">"Boston 1 e-waiver"


• Make sure to check our Facebook, </a><a href="http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook">http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook for practice announcements and cancellations -- especially in the early and later parts of season with potentially colder night practices. 

Weekly practices are every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday unless a race is scheduled or practice is cancelled.

Mon & Wed: 5:45pm - 8pm, meet 5.45pm on the grassy patch near the Barking Crab.
Sat: 10:45am - 1pm, meet 10.45am on the grassy patch near the Barking Crab.

Optional dinner/lunch or social activity afterwards!

Outdoor paddling means exposure to the weather and water! Be prepared to get wet!

• Clothing: Wear workout clothes, synthetic fibers that dry quickly are highly recommended. Bring dry clothes to change into afterwards.


• Footwear: Sandals or flip flops recommended. Some people go barefoot. Shoes and socks are not recommended.


• Other: Bring plenty of water and sunscreen. Expensive glasses or sunglasses are not recommended. 


All paddling equipment is provided (paddles, pfds). Locked locker provided on-site. Please bring as little as possible to practice as space is limited.

In the event of inclement weather, announcements will be made through the comments area of each meetup event, also in Twitter, Facebook and email alerts.

Sign up for our weekly emails and email alerts

Twitter: @Boston1Dboat

Facebook: http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook

Parking: Channelside Parking at 284 A Street. Enter at 29-41 Necco Street, off Melcher Street. Weekend $5 flat rate. Weekdays $8 flat rate (in after 3pm). More details can be found here: http://bit.ly/1Nxv1lw.

Restroom: Do not use the restrooms in the Barking Crab, use the public restrooms near the Daily Catch

Public Transport: Closest T stop is South Station on the red line.

Hope to see you there!

results.description:
Sponsored by:

Overview

Hack/Reduce and SimSpace are teaming up to put on the first in a series of Attack/Defend competitions where Boston area companies and red-teamers can come together, eat some food, drink some mid-afternoon (or breakfast) beer, and demonstrate (or build on) their l33t skills.

Our first event will be held in Kendall Square on April 23rd, starting @ 11 AM (space opening at 10 AM).  The event will provide a unique opportunity for like minded folks to get together, network, and see SimSpace’s Cyber Range in action. This particular event takes a new approach on the Jeopardy style and will consist of 5 hosts per team network.  People of all skill sets are welcome, but if the words nmap, burp, metasploit, or kali don’t mean anything to you, you may want to bring a friend!

Please note that we will be capturing and creating an open dataset from this event. The dataset will be shared with participants from the event so that they can evaluate and improve their own research.

Format

Each team gets their own network consisting of full operating systems and configured with subtle, yet real world vulnerabilities and/or misconfigurations. Teams are required to use real world scanners, exploitation tools, and post exploitation tactics to capture the flags.

This is a great time to learn and think about networks with a true ‘black hat’ on. All participants should be prepared for a game that tests their skills with real hacker tools and tactics.

Breakdown and Scoring

• At the start of the event, each team will be given access to their clone of the “Red Team Challenge” network.

• Teams will be tasked with capturing 2 flags per host.Locations of flags will be located on the scoreboard within each teams dashboard.

• Flags are assigned point values, not all flags are created equal, and the team with the most points at the end wins.

Register Your Team

We ask that teams contain no more than 4 players.

If you are signing up to participate, we encourage you to have a technical understanding of how networks operate. This will not be a training event.
results.name: Red Team Challenge - Capture the Flag Event

results.description:
Hey Everyone one please see the description below for the book entitled:  

The Half Has Never Been Told: Slavery and the Making of American Capitalism by Edward Baptist


Americans tend to cast slavery as a pre-modern institution—the nation’s original sin, perhaps, but isolated in time and divorced from America’s later success. But to do so robs the millions who suffered in bondage of their full legacy.


As historian Edward Baptist reveals in The Half Has Never Been Told, the expansion of slavery in the first eight decades after American independence drove the evolution and modernization of the United States. In the span of a single lifetime, the South grew from a narrow coastal strip of worn-out tobacco plantations to a continental cotton empire, and the United States grew into a modern, industrial, and capitalist economy. Until the Civil War, Baptist explains, the most important American economic innovations were ways to make slavery ever more profitable. Through forced migration and torture, slave owners extracted continual increases in efficiency from enslaved African Americans. Thus the United States seized control of the world market for cotton, the key raw material of the Industrial Revolution, and became a wealthy nation with global influence.


Told through intimate slave narratives, plantation records, newspapers, and the words of politicians, entrepreneurs, and escaped slaves, The Half Has Never Been Told offers a radical new interpretation of American history. It forces readers to reckon with the violence at the root of American supremacy, but also with the survival and resistance that brought about slavery’s end—and created a culture that sustains America’s deepest dreams of freedom.
results.name: The Half Has Never Been Told...etc....by Edward E. Baptist

The concert will be presented on the lawn of the Endicott Estate, or, in the event or rain, under a large tent. Note the concert coincides with the road race’s in-person registration day (Saturday), the day before the race (Sunday).

Straight off the boat from Dublin Ireland, Cormac Marnell hails from the South side in Ballinteer. Cormac began playing music only five years ago. As one of the founding members of The Locals and then The Auld Locals, Cormac made a name for himself in the Boston pub scene. He went on to open up for The Saw Doctors as well as playing every major Irish Festival in New England. Cormac performs on the 5 string banjo, tin whistle and harmonica as well as lead vocals.


Dave Bowman hails from Martha's Vineyard off the coast of Cape Cod and has had an interest in Irish traditional music for nearly a decade. Skilled on the tin whistle, the mandolin, octave mandolin and tenor banjo Dave lends a diverse range of talents to the folk stylings of the band. Dave is a capable singer who likes to perform classics like "The Handsome Cabin Boy" and "Tom Dooley".

Free, donations accepted.
Reservations not required, but appreciated.

This concert is supported in part by a grant from the Dedham Cultural Council, a local agency which is supported by the Massachusetts Cultural Council, a state agency. Free-will donations ($5-10pp) accepted.

The concert will be presented on the lawn of the Endicott Estate, or, in the event or rain, under a large tent. Note the concert coincides with the road race’s in-person registration day (Saturday), the day before the James Joyce Ramble (Sunday).

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
